Pursuing Overall Welfare in Federated Learning
through Sequential Decision Making

Seok-Ju Hahn    Gi-Soo Kim    Junghye Lee
Abstract

In traditional federated learning, a single global model cannot perform equally well for all clients. Therefore, the need to achieve the client-level fairness in federated system has been emphasized, which can be realized by modifying the static aggregation scheme for updating the global model to an adaptive one, in response to the local signals of the participating clients. Our work reveals that existing fairness-aware aggregation strategies can be unified into an online convex optimization framework, in other words, a central server’s sequential decision making process. To enhance the decision making capability, we propose simple and intuitive improvements for suboptimal designs within existing methods, presenting AAggFF. Considering practical requirements, we further subdivide our method tailored for the cross-device and the cross-silo settings, respectively. Theoretical analyses guarantee sublinear regret upper bounds for both settings: 𝒪​(T​log⁡K)𝒪𝑇𝐾\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{T\log{K}}) for the cross-device setting, and 𝒪​(K​log⁡T)𝒪𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}(K\log{T}) for the cross-silo setting, with K𝐾K clients and T𝑇T federation rounds. Extensive experiments demonstrate that the federated system equipped with AAggFF achieves better degree of client-level fairness than existing methods in both practical settings. Code is available at https://github.com/vaseline555/AAggFF.

Machine Learning, ICML

1 Introduction

Federated Learning (FL) has been posed as an effective strategy to acquire a global model without centralizing data, therefore with no compromise in privacy (McMahan et al., 2017). It is commonly assumed that the central server coordinates the whole FL procedure by repeatedly aggregating local updates from participating K𝐾K clients during T𝑇T rounds.

Since each client updates the copy of a global model with its own data, variability across clients’ data distributions causes many problems (Kairouz et al., 2021; Li et al., 2020b). The client-level fairness (Chen et al., 2023) is one of the main problems affected by such a statistical heterogeneity (Kairouz et al., 2021; Li et al., 2020b; Mohri et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019). Although the performance of a global model is high in average, some clients may be more benefited than others, resulting in violation of the client-level fairness. In this situation, there inevitably exists a group of clients who cannot utilize the trained global model due to its poor performance. This is a critical problem in practice since the underperformed groups may lose motivation to participate in the FL system. To remedy this problem, previous works (Mohri et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019, 2020a; Hu et al., 2022; Zhang et al., 2022) proposed to modify the static aggregation scheme into an adaptive aggregation strategy, according to given local signals (e.g., losses or gradients). In detail, the server re-weights local updates by assigning larger mixing coefficients to higher local losses.

When updating the mixing coefficients, however, only a few bits are provided to the server, compared to the update of a model parameter. For example, suppose that there exist K𝐾K clients in the FL system, each of which has N𝑁N local samples. When all clients participate in each round, K​N𝐾𝑁KN samples are used effectively for updating a new global model 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. On the contrary, only K𝐾K bits (e.g., local losses: F1​(𝜽),…,FK​(𝜽)subscript𝐹1𝜽…subscript𝐹𝐾𝜽F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta}),...,F_{K}(\boldsymbol{\theta})) are provided to the server for an update of mixing coefficients. This is aggravated in cases where K𝐾K is too large, thus client sampling is inevitably required. In this case, the server is provided with far less than K𝐾K signals, which hinders faithful update of the mixing coefficients.

For sequentially updating a status in this sample-deficient situation, the Online Convex Optimization (OCO) framework is undoubtedly the best solution. Interestingly, we discovered that most existing adaptive aggregation strategies can be readily unified into the OCO framework. Starting from this unification result, we propose an improved design for a fair FL algorithm in the view of sequential decision making. Since there exist OCO algorithms specialized for the setting where the decision space is a simplex (i.e., same as the domain of the mixing coefficient), these may be adopted to FL setting with some modifications for practical constraints.

In practice, FL is subdivided into two settings: cross-silo setting and cross-device setting (Kairouz et al., 2021). For K𝐾K clients and T𝑇T training rounds, each setting requires a different dependency on K𝐾K and T𝑇T. In the cross-silo setting, the number of clients (e.g., institutions) is small and usually less than the number of rounds (i.e., K<T𝐾𝑇K<T). e.g., K=20𝐾20K=20 institutions with T=200𝑇200T=200 rounds (Dayan et al., 2021). On the other hand, in the cross-device setting, the number of clients (e.g., mobile devices) is larger than the number of rounds (K>T𝐾𝑇K>T). e.g., K=1.5×106𝐾1.5superscript106K=1.5\times 10^{6} with T=3,000𝑇3000T=3,000 rounds (Hard et al., 2018). In designing an FL algorithm, these conditions should be reflected for the sake of practicality.

Contributions

We propose AAggFF, a sequential decision making framework for the central server in FL tailored for inducing client-level fairness in the system. The contributions of our work are summarized as follows.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    We unify existing fairness-aware adaptive aggregation methods into an OCO framework and propose better online decision making designs for pursuing client-level fairness by the central server. (Section 3)

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    We propose AAggFF, which is designed to enhance the client-level fairness, and further specialize our method into two practical settings: AAggFF-S for cross-silo FL and AAggFF-D for cross-device FL. (Section 4)

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    We provide regret analyses on the behavior of two algorithms, AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D, presenting sublinear regrets. (Section 5)

  4. ∙∙\bullet

    We evaluate AAggFF on extensive benchmark datasets for realistic FL scenarios with other baselines. AAggFF not only boosts the worst-performing clients but also maintains overall performance. (Section 6)

2 Related Works

Client-Level Fairness in Federated Learning

The statistical heterogeneity across clients often causes non-uniform performances of a single global model on participating clients, which is also known as the violation of client-level fairness. Fairness-aware FL algorithms aim to eliminate such inequality to achieve uniform performance across all clients. There are mainly two approaches to address the problem (Chen et al., 2023): a single model approach, and a personalization approach. This paper mainly focuses on the former, which is usually realized by modifying the FL objective, such as a minimax fairness objective (Mohri et al., 2019) (which is also solved by multi-objective optimization (Hu et al., 2022) and is also modified to save a communication cost (Deng et al., 2020)), alpha-fairness (Mo & Walrand, 2000) objective (Li et al., 2019), suppressing outliers (i.e., clients having high losses) by tilted objective (Li et al., 2020a), and adopting the concept of proportional fairness to reach Nash equilibrium in performance distributions (Zhang et al., 2022). While the objective can be directly aligned with existing notions of fairness, it is not always a standard for the design of a fair FL algorithm. Notably, most of works share a common underlying principle: assigning more weights to a local update having larger losses.

Definition 2.1.

(Client-Level Fairness; Definition 1 of (Li et al., 2019), Section 4.2 of (Chen et al., 2023)) We informally define the notion of client-level fairness in FL as the status where a trained global model yields uniformly good performance across all participating clients. Note that uniformity can be measured by the spread of performances.

Online Decision Making

The OCO framework is designed for making sequential decisions with the best utilities, having solid theoretical backgrounds. It aims to minimize the cumulative mistakes of a decision maker (e.g., central sever), given a response of the environment (e.g., losses from clients) for finite rounds t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]. The cumulative mistakes of the learner are usually denoted as the cumulative regret (see (5)), and the learner can achieve sublinear regret in finite rounds using well-designed OCO algorithms (Shalev-Shwartz et al., 2012; McMahan, 2017; Orabona, 2019). In designing an OCO algorithm, two main frameworks are mainly considered: Online Mirror Descent (OMD) (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth et al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003) and Follow-The-Regularized-Leader (FTRL) (Abernethy et al., 2009; Hazan & Kale, 2010; Agarwal & Hazan, 2005; Shalev-Shwartz & Singer, 2006). One of popular instantiations of both frameworks is the Online Portfolio Selection (OPS) algorithm, of which decision space is restricted to a probability simplex. The universal portfolio algorithm is the first that yields an optimal theoretical regret, 𝒪​(K​log⁡T)𝒪𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}(K\log{T})) despite its heavy computation (𝒪​(K4​T14)𝒪superscript𝐾4superscript𝑇14\mathcal{O}(K^{4}T^{14})) (Cover, 1991), the Online Gradient Descent (Zinkevich, 2003) and the Exponentiated Gradient (EG) (Helmbold et al., 1998) show slightly worse regrets (both are 𝒪​(T)𝒪𝑇\mathcal{O}(\sqrt{T})), but can be executed in linear runtime in practice (𝒪​(K)𝒪𝐾\mathcal{O}(K)). Plus, the Online Newton Step (ONS) (Agarwal et al., 2006; Hazan et al., 2007) presents logarithmic regret with quadratic runtime in K𝐾K. Since these OPS algorithms are proven to perform well when the decision is a probability vector, we adopt them for finding adaptive mixing coefficients to achieve performance fairness in FL. To the best of our knowledge, we are the first to consider fair FL algorithms under the OCO framework.

3 Backgrounds

3.1 Mixing Coefficients in Federated Learning

The canonical objective of FL is given as follows:

min𝜽∈ℝd⁡F​(𝜽)=∑i=1Kpi​Fi​(𝜽).subscript𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑𝐹𝜽superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜽\begin{gathered}\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}F\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}F_{i}\left({\boldsymbol{\theta}}\right).\end{gathered} (1)

For K𝐾K clients, the FL objective aims to minimize the composite objectives, where client i𝑖i’s local objective is Fi​(𝜽)subscript𝐹𝑖𝜽F_{i}\left({\boldsymbol{\theta}}\right), weighted by a corresponding mixing coefficient pi≥0subscript𝑝𝑖0p_{i}\geq 0 (∑i=1Kpi=1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}=1), which is usually set to be a static value proportional to the sample size nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}: e.g., pi=nin,n=∑j=1Knjformulae-sequencesubscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑗p_{i}=\frac{n_{i}}{n},n=\sum_{j=1}^{K}n_{j}. Each local objective, Fi​(𝜽)=1ni​∑k=1niℒ​(ξk;𝜽)subscript𝐹𝑖𝜽1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑖ℒsubscript𝜉𝑘𝜽F_{i}\left({\boldsymbol{\theta}}\right)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{k=1}^{n_{i}}\mathcal{L}\left(\xi_{k};\boldsymbol{\theta}\right), is defined as the average of per-sample training loss ℒ​(⋅;𝜽)ℒ⋅𝜽\mathcal{L}\left(\cdot;\boldsymbol{\theta}\right) calculated from the local dataset, 𝒟i={ξk}k=1nisubscript𝒟𝑖superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}=\{\xi_{k}\}_{k=1}^{n_{i}}. Denote ∥⋅∥p\|\cdot\|_{p} as an Lpsubscript𝐿𝑝L_{p}-norm and ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1} as a probability simplex where ΔK−1={𝒒∈ℝK:qi≥0,‖𝒒‖1=1}subscriptΔ𝐾1conditional-set𝒒superscriptℝ𝐾formulae-sequencesubscript𝑞𝑖0subscriptnorm𝒒11\Delta_{K-1}=\left\{\boldsymbol{q}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}:q_{i}\geq 0,\|\boldsymbol{q}\|_{1}=1\right\}. Note that the mixing coefficient is a member of ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1}.

In vanilla FL, the role of the server to solve (1) is to naively add up local updates into a new global model by weighting each update with the static mixing coefficient proportional to nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i}. As the fixed scheme often violates the client-level fairness, the server should use adaptive mixing coefficients to pursue overall welfare across clients. This can be modeled as an optimization w.r.t. 𝒑∈ΔK−1𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, apart from (1).

3.2 Online Convex Optimization as a Unified Language

To mitigate the performance inequalities across clients, adaptive mixing coefficients can be estimated in response to local signals (e.g., local losses of a global model). Intriguingly, the adaptive aggregation strategies in existing fair FL methods (McMahan et al., 2017; Mohri et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019, 2020a; Zhang et al., 2022) can be readily unified into one framework, borrowing the language of OCO.

Remark 3.1.

Suppose we want to solve a minimization problem defined in (2). For all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], it aims to minimize a decision loss ℓ(t)​(𝒑)=−⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=-\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle (where ⟨⋅,⋅⟩⋅⋅\left\langle\cdot,\cdot\right\rangle is an inner product) defined by a response 𝒓(t)∈ℝKsuperscript𝒓𝑡superscriptℝ𝐾\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} and a decision 𝒑∈ΔK−1𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, with a regularizer R​(𝒑)𝑅𝒑R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) having a constant step size η∈ℝ≥0𝜂subscriptℝabsent0\eta\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}.

𝒑(t+1)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡ℓ(t)​(𝒑)+η​R​(𝒑)superscript𝒑𝑡1subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑𝜂𝑅𝒑\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+\eta R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) (2)

As long as the regularizer R​(𝒑)𝑅𝒑R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) in the Remark 3.1 is fixed as the negative entropy, i.e., R​(𝒑)=∑i=1Kpi​log⁡pi𝑅𝒑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i}, this subsumes aggregation strategies proposed in FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), AFL (Mohri et al., 2019), q-FFL (Li et al., 2019), TERM (Li et al., 2020a), and PropFair (Zhang et al., 2022). It has an update as follows.

pi(t+1)∝pi(t)​exp⁡(ri(t)/η)proportional-tosubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖𝜂\displaystyle p^{(t+1)}_{i}\propto{p^{(t)}_{i}\exp\left(r^{(t)}_{i}/\eta\right)} (3)

This is widely known as EG (Helmbold et al., 1998), a special realization of OMD (Nemirovskij & Yudin, 1983; Warmuth et al., 1997; Beck & Teboulle, 2003). We summarize how existing methods can be unified under this OCO framework in Table 1. The detailed derivations of mixing coefficients from each method are provided in Appendix A.1.

To sum up, we can interpret the aggregation mechanism in FL is secretly a result of the server’s sequential decision making behind the scene. Since the sequential learning scheme is well-behaved in a sample-deficient setting, adopting OCO is surely a suitable tactic for the server in that only a few bits are provided to update the mixing coefficients in each FL round, e.g, the number of local responses collected from the clients is at most K𝐾K. However, existing methods have not been devised with sequential decision making in mind. Therefore, one can easily find suboptimal designs inherent in existing methods from an OCO perspective.

3.3 Sequential Probability Assignment

To address the client-level fairness, the server should make an adaptive mixing coefficient vector, 𝒑(t)∈ΔK−1superscript𝒑𝑡subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\in\Delta_{K-1}, for each round t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]. In other words, the server needs to assign appropriate probabilities sequentially to local updates in every FL communication round.

Notably, this fairly resembles OPS, which seeks to maximize an investor’s cumulative profits on a set of K𝐾K assets during T𝑇T periods, by assigning his/her wealth 𝒑∈ΔK−1𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1} to each asset every time. In the OPS, the investor observes a price of all assets, 𝒓(t)∈ℝKsuperscript𝒓𝑡superscriptℝ𝐾\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} for each time t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T] and accumulates corresponding wealth according to the portfolio 𝒑(t)∈ΔK−1superscript𝒑𝑡subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\in\Delta_{K-1}. After T𝑇T periods, achieved cumulative profits is represented as ∏t=1T(1+⟨𝒑(t),𝒓(t)⟩)superscriptsubscriptproduct𝑡1𝑇1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝒓𝑡\prod_{t=1}^{T}\left(1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right), or in the form of logarithmic growth ratio, ∑t=1Tlog⁡(1+⟨𝒑(t),𝒓(t)⟩)superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝒓𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\log\left(1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right). In other words, one can view that OPS algorithms adopt negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss.

Definition 3.2.

(Negative Logarithmic Growth as a Decision Loss) For all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], define a decision loss ℓ(t):ΔK−1×ℝK→ℝ:superscriptℓ𝑡→subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptℝ𝐾ℝ\ell^{(t)}:\Delta_{K-1}\times\mathbb{R}^{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} as follows.

ℓ(t)​(𝒑)=−log⁡(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩),superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑1𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡\begin{gathered}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p})=-\log(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle),\end{gathered} (4)

where 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p} is a decision vector in ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1} and 𝒓(t)superscript𝒓𝑡\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)} is a response vector given at time t𝑡t.

Again, the OPS algorithm can serve as a metaphor for the central server’s fairness-aware online decision making in FL. For example, one can regard a response (i.e., local losses) of K𝐾K clients at a specific round t𝑡t the same as returns of assets on the day t𝑡t. Similarly, by considering cumulative losses (i.e., cumulative wealth) achieved until t𝑡t, the server can determine the next mixing coefficients (i.e., portfolio ratios) in ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1}. In the same context, the negative logarithmic growth can also be adopted as the decision loss. Accordingly, we can adopt well-established OPS strategies for achieving client-level fairness in FL.

Including OPS, a de facto standard objective for OCO is to minimize the regret defined in (5), with regard to the best decision in hindsight, 𝒑⋆≜arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1​∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝒑)≜superscript𝒑⋆subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\triangleq\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}), given all decisions {𝒑(1),…,𝒑(T)}superscript𝒑1…superscript𝒑𝑇\{\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)},...,\boldsymbol{p}^{(T)}\}. (Shalev-Shwartz et al., 2012; McMahan, 2017; Orabona, 2019)

Regret(T)​(𝒑⋆)=∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))−∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝒑⋆)superscriptRegret𝑇superscript𝒑⋆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑⋆\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star})=\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)})-\sum\nolimits_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\end{gathered} (5)

In finite time T𝑇T, an online decision making strategy should guarantee that the regret grows sublinearly. Therefore, when OPS strategies are modified for the fair FL, we should check if the strategy can guarantee vanishing regret upper bound in T𝑇T. Besides, we should also consider the dependency on K𝐾K due to practical constraints of the federated system.

4 Proposed Methods

4.1 Improved Design for Better Decision Making

From the Remark 3.1 and Table 1, one can easily notice suboptimal designs of existing methods in terms of OCO, as follows.

  1. a)

    Existing methods are stateless in making a new decision, pi(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖p^{(t+1)}_{i}. The previous decision is ignored as a fixed value (pi(t)=ni/nsubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛p^{(t)}_{i}=n_{i}/n) in the subsequent decision making. This naive reliance on static coefficients still runs the risk of violating client-level fairness.

  2. b)

    The decision maker sticks to a fixed and arbitrary step size η𝜂\eta, or a fixed regularizer R​(𝒑)𝑅𝒑R(\boldsymbol{p}) across t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], which can significantly affect the performance of OCO algorithms and should be manually selected.

  3. c)

    The decision loss is neither Lipschitz continuous nor strictly convex, which is related to achieving a sublinear regret.

As a remedy for handling a and b, the OMD objective for the server (i.e., (2)) can be replaced as follows.

𝒑(t+1)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1​∑τ=1tℓ(τ)​(𝒑)+R(t+1)​(𝒑)superscript𝒑𝑡1subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptℓ𝜏𝒑superscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑\displaystyle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}\ell^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) (6)

This is also known as FTRL objective (Abernethy et al., 2009; Hazan & Kale, 2010; Agarwal & Hazan, 2005; Shalev-Shwartz & Singer, 2006), which is inherently a stateful sequential decision making algorithm that adapts to histories of decision losses, ∑τ=1tℓ(τ)​(𝒑)superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptℓ𝜏𝒑\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\ell^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right), where ℓ(t):ΔK−1×ℝK→ℝ:superscriptℓ𝑡→subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptℝ𝐾ℝ\ell^{(t)}:\Delta_{K-1}\times\mathbb{R}^{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, with the time-varying regularizer R(t):ΔK−1→ℝ:superscript𝑅𝑡→subscriptΔ𝐾1ℝR^{(t)}:\Delta_{K-1}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}. Note that the time-varying regularizer is sometimes represented as, η(t+1)​R​(𝒑)superscript𝜂𝑡1𝑅𝒑\eta^{(t+1)}R(\boldsymbol{p}), a fixed regularizer R​(𝒑)𝑅𝒑R\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right) multiplied by a time-varying step size, η(t+1)∈ℝ≥0superscript𝜂𝑡1subscriptℝabsent0\eta^{(t+1)}\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}, which can later be automatically determined from the regret analysis (see e.g., Remark 4.5).

Additionally, when equipped with the negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss (i.e., (4)), the problem c can be addressed due to its strict convexity and Lipscthiz continuity. (See Lemma 4.1) Note that when the loss function is convex, we can run the FTRL with a linearized loss (i.e., ℓ~(t)​(𝒑)=⟨𝒑,𝒈(t)⟩superscript~ℓ𝑡𝒑𝒑superscript𝒈𝑡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\rangle where 𝒈(t)=∇ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))superscript𝒈𝑡∇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)). This is useful in that a closed-form update can be obtained thanks to the properties of the Fenchel conjugate (see Remark 4.5).

4.2 AAggFF: Adaptive Aggregation for Fair Federated Learning

Based on the improved objective design derived from the FTRL, we now introduce our methods, AAggFF, an acronym of Adaptive Aggregation for Fair Federated Learning). Mirroring the practical requirements of FL, we further subdivide into two algorithms: AAggFF-S for the cross-silo setting and AAggFF-D for the cross-device setting.

4.2.1 AAggFF-S: Algorithm for the Cross-Silo Federated Learning

In the cross-silo setting, it is typically assumed that all K𝐾K clients participate in T𝑇T rounds, since there are a moderately small number of clients in the FL system. Therefore, the server’s stateful decision making is beneficial for enhancing overall welfare across federation rounds. This is also favorable since existing OPS algorithms can be readily adopted.

Online Newton Step (Agarwal et al., 2006; Hazan et al., 2007)

The ONS algorithm updates a new decision as follows (α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta are constants to be determined).

𝒑(t+1)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1​∑τ=1tℓ~(τ)​(𝒑)+α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t(⟨𝒈(τ),𝒑−𝒑(τ)⟩)2superscript𝒑𝑡1subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript~ℓ𝜏𝒑𝛼2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝒑𝜏2\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}\\ +\frac{\beta}{2}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}(\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\rangle)^{2}\end{gathered} (7)

The ONS can be reduced to the FTRL objective introduced in (6). It can be retrieved when we use a linearized loss, ℓ~(t)​(𝒑)=⟨𝒑,𝒈(t)⟩superscript~ℓ𝑡𝒑𝒑superscript𝒈𝑡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\rangle, and the time-varying proximal regularizer, defined as R(t+1)​(𝒑)=α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t(⟨𝒈(τ),𝒑−𝒑(τ)⟩)2superscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑𝛼2subscriptsuperscriptnorm𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝒑𝜏2R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|^{2}_{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2}.

We choose ONS in that its regret is optimal in T𝑇T, which is also a dominating constant for the cross-silo FL setting: 𝒪​(L∞​K​log⁡T)𝒪subscript𝐿𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}(L_{\infty}K\log{T}) regret upper bound, where L∞subscript𝐿L_{\infty} is the Lipschitz constant of decision loss w.r.t. ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_{\infty}. That is, L∞subscript𝐿L_{\infty} should be finite for a vanishing regret (see Theorem 5.1).

Necessity of Bounded Response

Note that the Lipchitz continuity of the negative logarithmic growth as a decision loss is determined as follows.

Lemma 4.1.

For all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], suppose each entry of a response vector 𝐫(t)∈ℝKsuperscript𝐫𝑡superscriptℝ𝐾\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\in\mathbb{R}^{K} is bounded as ri(t)∈[C1,C2]superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2r_{i}^{(t)}\in[C_{1},C_{2}] for some constants C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} satisfying 0<C1<C20subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶20<C_{1}<C_{2}. Then, the decision loss ℓ(t)superscriptℓ𝑡\ell^{(t)} defined in (4) is C21+C1subscript𝐶21subscript𝐶1\frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}}-Lipschitz continuous in ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1} w.r.t. ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_{\infty}.

From now on, all proofs are deferred to Appendix A.2. According to the Lemma 4.1, the Lipschitz constant of the decision loss, L∞subscript𝐿L_{\infty}, is dependent upon the range of a response vector’s element. While from the unification result in Table 1, one can easily notice that the response is constructed from local losses collected in round t𝑡t, Fi​(𝜽(t))∈ℝ≥0,i∈[K]formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptℝabsent0𝑖delimited-[]𝐾F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})\in\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0},i\in[K].

This is a scalar value calculated from a local training set of each client, using the current model 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} before its local update. Since the local loss function is typically unbounded above (e.g., cross-entropy), it should be transformed into bounded values to satisfy the Lipschitz continuity. In existing fair FL methods, however, all responses are not bounded above, thus we cannot guarantee the Lipschitz continuity.

To ensure a bounded response, we propose to use a transformation denoted as ρ(t)​(⋅)superscript𝜌𝑡⋅\rho^{(t)}(\cdot), inspired by the cumulative distribution function (CDF) as follows.

Definition 4.2.

(CDF-driven Response Transformation) We define ri(t)≡ρ(t)​(Fi​(𝜽(t)))superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡superscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡r_{i}^{(t)}\equiv\rho^{(t)}\left({F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)})}\right), each element of the response vector is defined from the corresponding entry of a local loss by an element-wise mapping ρ(t):ℝ≥0→[C1,C2]:superscript𝜌𝑡→subscriptℝabsent0subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2\rho^{(t)}:\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\rightarrow[C_{1},C_{2}], given a pre-defined CDF as:

ρ(t)​(Fi​(𝜽(t)))≜C1+(C2−C1)​CDF​(Fi​(𝜽(t))F¯(t)),≜superscript𝜌𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1CDFsubscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡superscript¯F𝑡\displaystyle\rho^{(t)}\left({F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right)}\right)\triangleq C_{1}+(C_{2}-C_{1})\texttt{CDF}\left(\frac{F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right)}{\bar{\mathrm{F}}^{(t)}}\right), (8)

where F¯(t)=1|S(t)|​∑i∈S(t)Fi​(𝜽(t))superscript¯F𝑡1superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡\bar{\mathrm{F}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{\lvert S^{(t)}\rvert}\sum_{i\in S^{(t)}}F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right), and S(t)superscript𝑆𝑡S^{(t)} is an index set of available clients in t𝑡t.

Note again that the larger mixing coefficient should be assigned for the larger local loss. In such a perspective, using the CDF for transforming a loss value is an acceptable approach in that the CDF value is a good indicator for estimating “how large a specific local loss is”, relative to local losses from other clients. To instill the comparative nature, local losses are divided by the average of observed losses in time t𝑡t before applying the transformation. As a result, all local losses are centered on 1 in expectation. See Appendix B.1 for detailed discussions.

In summary, the whole procedure of AAggFF-S is illustrated as a pseudocode in Algorithm 2.

4.2.2 AAggFF-D: Algorithm for the Cross-Device Federated Learning

Unlike the cross-silo setting, we cannot be naïvely edopt existing OCO algorithms for finding adaptive mixing coefficients in the cross-device setting. It is attributed to the large number of participating clients in this special setting. Since the number of participating clients (K𝐾K) is massive (e.g., Android users are over 3 billion (Curry, 2023)), the dependence on K𝐾K in terms of regret bound and algorithm runtime is as significant as a total communication round T𝑇T.

Linear Runtime OCO Algorithm

The ONS has regret proportional to K𝐾K and runs in 𝒪​(K2+K3)𝒪superscript𝐾2superscript𝐾3\mathcal{O}\left(K^{2}+K^{3}\right)111A generalized projection required for the Online Newton Step that can be solved in 𝒪~​(K3)~𝒪superscript𝐾3\tilde{\mathcal{O}}\left(K^{3}\right) (Agarwal et al., 2006; Hazan et al., 2007). per round, which is nearly impossible to be adopted for the cross-device FL setting due to large K𝐾K, even though the logarithmic regret is guaranteed in T𝑇T. Instead, we can exploit the variant of EG adapted to FTRL (Orabona, 2019), which can be run in 𝒪​(K)𝒪𝐾\mathcal{O}\left(K\right) time per round.

𝒑(t+1)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1​∑τ=1tℓ~(τ)​(𝒑)+η(t+1)​R​(𝒑),superscript𝒑𝑡1subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript~ℓ𝜏𝒑superscript𝜂𝑡1𝑅𝒑\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum\nolimits_{\tau=1}^{t}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+\eta^{(t+1)}R(\boldsymbol{p}),\end{gathered} (9)

where η(t)superscript𝜂𝑡\eta^{(t)} is non-decreasing step size across t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], and R​(𝒑)=∑i=1Kpi​log⁡pi𝑅𝒑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖R(\boldsymbol{p})=\sum\nolimits_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i} is a negative entropy regularizer. Still, the regret bound gets worse than that of ONS, as 𝒪​(L∞​T​log⁡K)𝒪subscript𝐿𝑇𝐾\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right) (see Theorem 5.2).

Partially Observed Response

The large number of clients coerces the FL system to introduce the client sampling scheme in each round. Therefore, the decision maker (i.e., the central server) cannot always observe all entries of a response vector per round. This is problematic in terms of OCO, since OCO algorithms assume that they can acquire intact response vector for every round t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]. Instead, when the client sampling is introduced, the learner can only observe entries of sampled client indices in the round t𝑡t, denoted as S(t)superscript𝑆𝑡S^{(t)}.

To make a new decision using a partially observed response vector, the effect of unobserved entries should be appropriately estimated. We solve this problem by adopting a doubly robust (DR) estimator (Robins et al., 1994; Bang & Robins, 2005) for the expectation of the response vector. The rationale behind the adoption of the DR estimator is the fact that the unobserved entries are missing data.

For handling the missingness problem, the DR estimator combines inverse probability weighting (IPW (Auer et al., 2002)) estimator and imputation mechanism, where the former is to adjust the weight of observed entries by the inverse of its observation probability (i.e., client sampling probability), and the latter is to fill unobserved entries with appropriate values specific to a given task.

Similar to the IPW estimator, the DR estimator is an unbiased estimator when the true observation probability is known. Since we sample clients uniformly at random without replacement, the observation probability is known (i.e., C∈(0,1)𝐶01C\in(0,1)) to the algorithm.

Lemma 4.3.

Denote C=P​(i∈S(t))𝐶𝑃𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡C=P\left(i\in S^{(t)}\right) as a client sampling probability of a cross-device FL system for every round t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T]. The DR estimator 𝐫˘(t)superscript˘𝐫𝑡\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)}, of which element is defined in (10) is an unbiased estimator of given partially observed response vector 𝐫(t)superscript𝐫𝑡\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}. i.e., 𝔼​[𝐫˘(t)]=𝐫(t)𝔼delimited-[]superscript˘𝐫𝑡superscript𝐫𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)}\right]=\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}.

r˘i(t)=(1−𝕀​(i∈S(t))C)​r¯(t)+𝕀​(i∈S(t))C​ri(t),subscriptsuperscript˘𝑟𝑡𝑖1𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶superscript¯r𝑡𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖\begin{gathered}\breve{r}^{(t)}_{i}=\left(1-\frac{\mathbb{I}(i\in S^{(t)})}{C}\right)\mathrm{\bar{r}}^{(t)}+\frac{\mathbb{I}\left(i\in S^{(t)}\right)}{C}{r}^{(t)}_{i},\end{gathered} (10)

where r¯(t)=1|S(t)|​∑i∈S(t)ri(t)superscript¯r𝑡1superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑖𝑡\bar{\mathrm{r}}^{(t)}=\frac{1}{\left|S^{(t)}\right|}\sum_{i\in S^{(t)}}r_{i}^{(t)}.

Still, it is required to guarantee that the gradient vector from the DR estimator is also an unbiased estimator of a true gradient of a decision loss. Unfortunately, the gradient of a decision loss is not linear in the response vector due to its fractional form: 𝒈(t)=∇ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))=−𝒓(t)1+⟨𝒑(t),𝒓(t)⟩superscript𝒈𝑡∇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝒓𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝒓𝑡{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle}.

Therefore, we instead use linearly approximated gradient w.r.t. a response vector as follows.

Lemma 4.4.

Denote the gradient of a decision loss in terms of a response vector as 𝐠≡𝐡​(𝐫)=[h1​(𝐫),…,hK​(𝐫)]⊤=−𝐫1+⟨𝐩,𝐫⟩𝐠𝐡𝐫superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝐫…subscriptℎ𝐾𝐫top𝐫1𝐩𝐫\boldsymbol{g}\equiv\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}(\boldsymbol{r})=\left[h_{1}(\boldsymbol{r}),...,h_{K}(\boldsymbol{r})\right]^{\top}=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\right\rangle}. It can be linearized for the response vector into 𝐠~≡𝐡~​(𝐫)~𝐠~𝐡𝐫{\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}}\equiv\tilde{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r}), given a reference 𝐫0subscript𝐫0\boldsymbol{r}_{0} as follows. (Note that the superscript (t) is omitted for a brevity of notation)

𝒈≈𝒈~≡𝐡~​(𝒓)=−𝒓1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩+𝒓0​𝒑⊤​(𝒓−𝒓0)(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩)2𝒈~𝒈~𝐡𝒓𝒓1𝒑subscript𝒓0subscript𝒓0superscript𝒑top𝒓subscript𝒓0superscript1𝒑subscript𝒓02\begin{gathered}{\boldsymbol{g}}\approx{\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}}\equiv\tilde{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r})=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\right\rangle}+\frac{\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}_{0})}{(1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\right\rangle)^{2}}\end{gathered} (11)

Further denote 𝐠˘˘𝐠\breve{\boldsymbol{g}} as a gradient estimate from (11) using the DR estimator of a response vector according to (10),k at an arbitrary reference 𝐫0subscript𝐫0\boldsymbol{r}_{0}. Then, 𝐠˘˘𝐠\breve{\boldsymbol{g}} is an unbiased estimator of the linearized gradient of a decision loss at 𝐫0subscript𝐫0\boldsymbol{r}_{0}, which is close to the true gradient: 𝔼​[𝐠˘]=𝐠~≈𝐠𝔼delimited-[]˘𝐠~𝐠𝐠\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}\right]=\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}\approx\boldsymbol{g}.

As suggested in (10), we similarly set the reference as an average of observed responses at round t𝑡t, i.e., 𝒓0(t)=r¯(t)​𝟏Ksuperscriptsubscript𝒓0𝑡superscript¯r𝑡subscript1𝐾\boldsymbol{r}_{0}^{(t)}=\mathrm{\bar{r}}^{(t)}\boldsymbol{1}_{K}. It is a valid choice in that dominating unobserved entries are imputed by the average of observed responses as in (10).

To sum up, we can update a new decision using this unbiased and linearly approximated gradient estimator even if only a partially observed response vector is provided (i.e., mixing coefficients of unsampled clients can also be updated). Note that the linearized gradient calculated from the DR estimator, 𝒈˘˘𝒈\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}, has finite norm w.r.t. ∥⋅∥∞\|\cdot\|_{\infty} (see Lemma A.2).

Closed-Form Update

Especially for the cross-device setting, we can obtain a closed-form update of the objective (9), which is due to the property of Fenchel conjugate.

Remark 4.5.

The objective of AAggFF-D stated in (9) has a closed-form update formula as follows. (Orabona, 2019)

pi(t+1)∝exp⁡(−log⁡K​∑τ=1tg˘i(τ)L˘∞​t+1)proportional-tosubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡subscriptsuperscript˘𝑔𝜏𝑖subscript˘𝐿𝑡1\displaystyle{p}^{(t+1)}_{i}\propto{\exp\left(-\frac{\sqrt{\log{K}}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{g}^{(\tau)}_{i}}{\breve{L}_{\infty}\sqrt{t+1}}\right)} (12)

5 Regret Analysis

In this section, we provide theoretical guarantees of our methods, AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D in terms of sequential decision making. The common objective for OCO algorithms is to minimize the regret across a sequence of decision losses in eq. (5). We provide sublinear regret upper bounds in terms of T𝑇T as follows.

Theorem 5.1.

(Regret Upper Bound for AAggFF-S (i.e., ONS (Agarwal et al., 2006; Hazan et al., 2007))) With the notation in eq. (7), suppose for every 𝐩∈ΔK−1𝐩subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, and for every t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], let the decisions {𝐩(t):t∈[T]}conditional-setsuperscript𝐩𝑡𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}:t\in[T]\} be derived by AAggFF-S for K𝐾K clients during T𝑇T rounds in Algorithm 2. Then, the regret defined in eq. (5) is bounded above as follows, where α𝛼\alpha and β𝛽\beta are determined as α=4​K​L∞,β=14​L∞formulae-sequence𝛼4𝐾subscript𝐿𝛽14subscript𝐿\alpha=4KL_{\infty},\beta=\frac{1}{4L_{\infty}}.

Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)≤2​L∞​K​(1+log⁡(1+T16​K)).superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆2subscriptLK11T16K\displaystyle\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq 2L_{\infty}K\left(1+\log\left(1+\frac{T}{16K}\right)\right).\end{gathered}

From the Theorem 5.1, we can enjoy 𝒪​(L∞​K​log⁡T)𝒪subscript𝐿𝐾𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\log{T}\right) regret upper bound, which is an acceptable result, considering a typical assumption in the cross-silo setting (i.e., K<T𝐾𝑇K<T).

For the cross-device setting, we first present the full synchronization setting, which requires no extra adjustment.

Theorem 5.2.

(Regret Upper Bound for AAggFF-D with Full-Client Participation) With the notation in (9), suppose for every 𝐩∈ΔK−1𝐩subscriptΔ𝐾1\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}, and for every t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], let the decisions {𝐩(t):t∈[T]}conditional-setsuperscript𝐩𝑡𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\{\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}:t\in[T]\} be derived by AAggFF-D for K𝐾K clients with client sampling probability C=1𝐶1C=1 during T𝑇T rounds in Algorithm 3. Then, the regret defined in (5) is bounded above as follows.

Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)≤2​L∞​T​log⁡K.superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆2subscriptLTK\displaystyle\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq 2L_{\infty}\sqrt{T\log{K}}.\end{gathered}

When equipped with a client sampling, the randomness from the sampling should be considered. Due to local losses of selected clients can only be observed, AAggFF-D should be equipped with the unbiased estimator of a response vector (from Lemma 4.3) and a corresponding linearly approximated gradient vector (from Lemma 4.4). Since they are unbiased estimators, the expected regret is also the same.

Corollary 5.3.

(Regret Upper Bound for AAggFF-D with Partial-Client Participation) With the client sampling probability C∈(0,1)𝐶01C\in(0,1), the DR estimator of a partially observed response 𝐫˘(t)superscript˘𝐫𝑡\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)} and corresponding linearized gradient 𝐠˘(t)superscript˘𝐠𝑡\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)} for all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], the regret defined in (5) is bounded above in expectation as follows.

𝔼​[Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)]≤𝒪​(L∞​T​log⁡K).𝔼delimited-[]superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆𝒪subscript𝐿𝑇𝐾\displaystyle\begin{gathered}\mathbb{E}\left[\text{Regret}^{(T)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star})\right]\leq\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right).\end{gathered}

6 Experimental Results

We design experiments to evaluate empirical performances of our proposed framework AAggFF, composed of sub-methods AAggFF-S and AAggFF-D.

Experimental Setup

We conduct experiments on datasets mirroring realistic scenarios in FL systems: multiple modalities (vision, text, speech, and tabular form) and natural data partitioning. We briefly summarize FL settings of each dataset in Table 4. For the cross-silo setting, we used Berka tabular dataset (Berka, 1999), MQP clinical text dataset (McCreery et al., 2020), and ISIC oncological image dataset (Codella et al., 2018) (also a part of FLamby benchmark (Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022)). For the cross-device setting, we used CelebA vision dataset (Liu et al., 2015), Reddit text dataset (both are parts of LEAF benchmark (Caldas et al., 2019)) and SpeechCommands audio dataset (Warden, 2018).

Instead of manually partitioning data to simulate statistical heterogeneity, we adopt natural client partitions inherent in each dataset. Each client dataset is split into an 80% training set and a 20% test set in a stratified manner where applicable. All experiments are run with 3 different random seeds after tuning hyperparameters. See Appendix C for full descriptions of the experimental setup.

Improvement in the Client-Level Fairness

We compare our methods with existing fair FL methods including FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017), AFL (Mohri et al., 2019), q-FedAvg (Li et al., 2019), TERM (Li et al., 2020a), FedMGDA (Hu et al., 2022), and PropFair (Zhang et al., 2022). Since AFL requires full synchronization of clients every round, it is only compared in the cross-silo setting.

In the cross-silo setting, we assume all K𝐾K clients participate in T𝑇T federation rounds (i.e., C=1𝐶1C=1), and in the cross-device setting, the client participation rate C∈(0,1)𝐶01C\in(0,1) is set to ensure 555 among K𝐾K clients are participating in each round. We evaluate each dataset using appropriate metrics for tasks as indicated under the dataset name in Table 2 and 3, where the average, the best (10%), the worst (10%), and Gini coefficient222The Gini coefficient is inflated by (×102absentsuperscript102\times 10^{2}) for readability. of clients’ performance distributions are reported with the standard deviation inside parentheses in gray color below the averaged metric.

From the results, we verify that AAggFF can lead to enhanced worst-case metric and Gini coefficient in both settings while retaining competitive average performance to other baselines. Remarkably, along with the improved worst-case performance, the small Gini coefficient indicates that performances of clients are close to each other, which is directly translated into the improved client-level fairness.

Connection to Accuracy Parity

As discussed in (Li et al., 2019), the client-level fairness can be loosely connected to existing fairness notion, the accuracy parity (Zafar et al., 2017). It is guaranteed if the accuracies in protected groups are equal to each other. While the accuracy parity requires equal performances among specific groups having protected attributes (Zafar et al., 2017; Cotter et al., 2019), this is too restrictive to be directly applied to FL settings, since each client cannot always be exactly corresponded to the concept of ‘a group’, and each client’s local distribution may not be partitioned by protected attributes in the federated system.

With a relaxation of the original concept, we adopt the notion of accuracy parity for measuring the degree of the client-level fairness in the federated system, i.e., we simply regard the group as each client. As a metric, we adopt the accuracy parity gap (Δ​AGΔAG\Delta\text{AG}) proposed by (Zhao et al., 2019; Chi et al., 2021), which is simply defined as an absolute difference between the performance of the best and the worst performing groups (clients). The results are in Table 5 and Table 6. It can be said that the smaller the Δ​AGΔAG\Delta\text{AG}, the more degree of the accuracy parity fairness (and therefore the client-level fairness) is achieved.

It should be noted that strictly achieving the accuracy parity can sometimes require sacrifice in the average performance. This is aligned with the result of Reddit dataset in Table 6, where FedMGDA (Hu et al., 2022) achieved the smallest Δ​AGΔAG\Delta\text{AG}, while its average performance is only 10.58 in Table 3. This is far lower than our proposed method’s average performance, 12.95. Except this case, AAggFF consistently shows the smallest Δ​AGΔAG\Delta\text{AG} than other baseline methods, which is important in the perspective of striking a good balance between overall utility and the client-level fairness.

Plug-and-Play Boosting

We additionally check if AAggFF can also boost other FL algorithms than FedAvg, such as FedAdam, FedAdagrad, FedYogi (Reddi et al., 2020) and FedProx (Li et al., 2020c). Since the sequential decision making procedure required in AAggFF is about finding a good mixing coefficient, 𝒑𝒑\boldsymbol{p}, this is orthogonal to the minimization of 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}. Thus, our method can be easily integrated into existing methods with no special modification, in a plug-and-play manner.

For the verification, we test with two more datasets, Heart (Janosi et al., 1988) and TinyImageNet (Le & Yang, 2015), each of which is suited for binary and multi-class classification (i.e., 200 classes in total). Since the Heart dataset is a part of FLamby benchmark (Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022), it has pre-defined K=4𝐾4K=4 clients. For the TinyImageNet dataset, we simulate statistical heterogeneity for K=1,000𝐾1000K=1,000 clients using Dirichlet distribution with a concentration of 0.010.010.01, following (Hsu et al., 2019). The results are in Table 7, where the upper cell represents the performance of a naive FL algorithm, and the lower cell contains a performance of the FL algorithm with AAggFF. While the average performance remains comparable, the worst performance is consistently boosted in both cross-silo and cross-device settings. This underpins the efficacy and flexibility of AAggFF, which can strengthen the fairness perspective of existing FL algorithms.

7 Limitations and Future Works

Our work suggests interesting future directions for a better FL system, which may also be a limitation of the current work. First, we can exploit side information (e.g., parameters of local updates) to not preserve all clients’ mixing coefficients, and filter out malicious signals for robustness. For example, the former can be realized by adopting other decision making schemes such as contextual Bayesian optimization (Char et al., 2019), and the latter can be addressed by clustered FL (Ghosh et al., 2020; Sattler et al., 2020) for a group-wise estimation of mixing coefficients. Both directions are promising and may improve the practicality of FL systems. Furthermore, the FTRL objective can be replaced by the Follow-The-Perturbed-Leader (FTPL) (Kalai & Vempala, 2005), of which random perturbation in decision making process can be directly linked to the differential privacy (DP (Dwork, 2006)) guarantee (McMillan, 2018), which is frequently considered for the cross-silo setting. Last but not least, further convergence analysis is required w.r.t. the parameter perspective along with mixing coefficients, e.g., resorting to bi-level optimization framework.

8 Conclusion

For improving the degree of the client-level fairness in FL, we first reveal the connection of existing fair FL methods with the OCO. To emphasize the sequential decision making perspective, we propose improved designs and further specialize them into two practical settings: cross-silo FL & cross-device FL. Our framework not only efficiently enhances a low-performing group of clients compared to existing baselines, but also maintains an acceptable average performance with theoretically guaranteed behaviors. It should also be noted that AAggFF requires no extra communication and no added local computation, which are significant constraints for serving FL-based services. With this scalability, our method can also improve the fairness of the performance distributions of existing FL algorithms without much modification to their original mechanism. By explicitly bringing the sequential decision making scheme to the front, we expect our work to open up new designs to promote the practicality and scalability of FL.

Impact Statement

Federated Learning (FL) poses a potential risk of skewed performance distributions toward partial sub-groups of clients. We believe that our proposed method can mitigate such an unfair situation in the FL system, thereby enhancing the trustworthiness of the FL system and social welfare. A potential concern is the situation where malicious clientd deliberately inflates their local signals to cause global updates to be biased towards themselves. To prevent such a catastrophic situation, we aim to improve the current work by exploiting information other than local losses, as mentioned in the Limitations and future work section. Authors are not aware of other critical ethical/social implications otherwise, but are open to discussing them if exist.

Appendix A Derivations & Proofs

A.1 Derivation of Mixing Coefficients from Existing Methods

In this section, we provide details of the unification of existing methods in the OCO framework, introduced in Section 3. We assume full-client participation for derivation, and we denote n=∑i=1Kni𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑖n=\sum_{i=1}^{K}n_{i} as a total sample size for the brevity of notation.

Suppose any FL algorithms follow the update formula in (13), where we define 𝒑(t+1)superscript𝒑𝑡1\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)} as a mixing coefficient vector discussed in Section 3.2.

𝜽(t+1)←𝜽(t)−(∑i=1Kpi(t+1)​(𝜽(t)−𝜽i(t+1))),←superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝑖\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{K}{p}^{(t+1)}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}_{i}\right)\right),\end{gathered} (13)

where 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)} is a global model in a previous round t𝑡t, 𝜽i(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝑖\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}_{i} is a local update from i𝑖i-th client starting from 𝜽(t)superscript𝜽𝑡\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}, and 𝜽(t+1)superscript𝜽𝑡1\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)} is a new global model updated by averaging local updates with corresponding mixing coefficient pi(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖p^{(t+1)}_{i}.

FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) The update of a global model from FedAvg is defined as follows.

𝜽(t+1)←𝜽(t)−(∑i=1Knin​(𝜽(t)−𝜽i(t+1))),←superscript𝜽𝑡1superscript𝜽𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛superscript𝜽𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝜽𝑡1𝑖\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}\leftarrow\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\left(\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t+1)}_{i}\right)\right),\end{gathered} (14)

where nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the sample size of client i𝑖i. Thus, we can regard pi(t+1)∝niproportional-tosubscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖subscript𝑛𝑖{p}^{(t+1)}_{i}\propto n_{i} in FedAvg.

AFL & q-FedAvg (Mohri et al., 2019; Li et al., 2019) The objective of AFL is a minimax objective defined as follows.

min𝜽∈ℝd⁡max𝒗∈ΔK−1​∑i=1Kvi​Fi​(𝜽),subscript𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑subscript𝒗subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑣𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝜽\begin{gathered}\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\max_{\boldsymbol{v}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum_{i=1}^{K}v_{i}F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right),\end{gathered} (15)

which is later subsumed by q-FedAvg as its special case for the algorithm-specific constant q𝑞q, where q→0→𝑞0q\rightarrow 0.

The objective of q-FedAvg is therefore defined with a nonnegative constant q𝑞q as follows.

min𝜽∈ℝd​∑i=1K1q+1​nin​Fiq+1​(𝜽)=min𝜽∈ℝd​∑i=1Knin​F~i​(𝜽),subscript𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾1𝑞1subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑞1𝜽subscript𝜽superscriptℝ𝑑superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑛𝑖𝑛subscript~𝐹𝑖𝜽\begin{gathered}\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{1}{q+1}\frac{n_{i}}{n}F_{i}^{q+1}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right)\\ =\min_{\boldsymbol{\theta}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\sum_{i=1}^{K}\frac{n_{i}}{n}\tilde{F}_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}\right),\end{gathered} (16)

which is reduced to FedAvg when q=0𝑞0q=0.

The update of a global model from (16) has been proposed in the form of a Newton style update by assuming L𝐿L-Lipschitz continuous gradient of each local objective (i.e., q-FedSGD) (Li et al., 2019).

A.2 Technical Lemmas

In this section, we provide technical lemmas and proofs (including deferred ones in the main text) required for proving Theorem 5.1, Theorem 5.2, and Corollary 5.3.

A.2.1 Strict Convexity of Decision Loss

Lemma A.1.

For all t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], the decision loss ℓ(t)superscriptℓ𝑡\ell^{(t)} defined in (4) satisfies following for γ∈(0,1)𝛾01\gamma\in(0,1), i.e., the decision loss is a strictly convex function of its first argument.

ℓ(t)​(γ​𝒑+(1−γ)​𝒒)<γ​ℓ(t)​(𝒑)+(1−γ)​ℓ(t)​(𝒒),∀𝒑,𝒒∈ΔK−1,𝒑≠𝒒.formulae-sequencesuperscriptℓ𝑡𝛾𝒑1𝛾𝒒𝛾superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑1𝛾superscriptℓ𝑡𝒒for-all𝒑formulae-sequence𝒒subscriptΔ𝐾1𝒑𝒒\begin{gathered}\ell^{(t)}\left(\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q}\right)<\gamma\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)+(1-\gamma)\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right),\forall\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{q}\in\Delta_{K-1},\boldsymbol{p}\neq\boldsymbol{q}.\end{gathered} (24)
Proof.

From the left-hand side, we have

ℓ(t)​(γ​𝒑+(1−γ)​𝒒)=−log⁡(1+⟨γ​𝒑+(1−γ)​𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩)=−log⁡(1+⟨γ​𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩+⟨(1−γ)​𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩)=−log⁡(γ​(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩)+(1−γ)​(1+⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩)).superscriptℓ𝑡𝛾𝒑1𝛾𝒒1𝛾𝒑1𝛾𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡1𝛾𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡1𝛾𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡𝛾1𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡1𝛾1𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡\begin{split}&\ell^{(t)}\left(\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q}\right)\\ =&-\log\left(1+\langle\gamma\boldsymbol{p}+(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle\right)\\ =&-\log\left(1+\langle\gamma\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle+\langle(1-\gamma)\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle\right)\\ =&-\log\left(\gamma(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)+(1-\gamma)(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right).\end{split} (25)

Since the negative of logarithm is strictly convex, the last term becomes

−log⁡(γ​(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩)+(1−γ)​(1+⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩))<γ​(−log⁡(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩))+(1−γ)​(−log⁡(1+⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩)),𝛾1𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡1𝛾1𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡𝛾1𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡1𝛾1𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡\begin{gathered}-\log\left(\gamma(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)+(1-\gamma)(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right)<\gamma\left(-\log(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right)+(1-\gamma)\left(-\log(1+\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle)\right),\end{gathered} (26)

which satisfies the definition of the strict convexity, thereby concludes the proof. ∎

A.2.2 Lipschitz Continuity of Decision Loss (Lemma 4.1)

From the definition of the Lipschitz continuity w.r.t. ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|, we need to check if the decision loss ℓ(t)superscriptℓ𝑡\ell^{(t)} satisfies following inequality for the constant L∞subscript𝐿L_{\infty}.

|ℓ(t)​(𝒑)−ℓ(t)​(𝒒)|≤L∞​‖𝒑−𝒒‖∞.superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑superscriptℓ𝑡𝒒subscript𝐿subscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑𝒒\begin{gathered}\left|\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)-\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right)\right|\leq L_{\infty}\left\|\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q}\right\|_{\infty}.\end{gathered} (27)
Proof.

From Lemma A.1, we have the following inequality from the convexity of the decision loss.

|ℓ(t)​(𝒑)−ℓ(t)​(𝒒)|≤|⟨∇ℓ(t)​(𝒑),𝒑−𝒒⟩|=|−⟨𝒑−𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩1+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩|=11+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩​|⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩−⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩|superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑superscriptℓ𝑡𝒒∇superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑𝒑𝒒𝒑𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡1𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡11𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡\begin{split}&\left|\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)-\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{q}\right)\right|\leq\left|\langle\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right),\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q}\rangle\right|\\ &=\left|-\frac{\langle\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}\right|\\ &=\frac{1}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle}\left|\left\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle-\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right|\end{split} (28)

Setting the denominator to be the minimum value, ⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle is C1subscript𝐶1C_{1}, we have the upper bound as follows.

11+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩​|⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩−⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩|≤11+⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩​max⁡(⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩,⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩)≤11+C1​max⁡(⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩,C1),11𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡11𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡11subscript𝐶1𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡subscript𝐶1\begin{split}&\frac{1}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle}\left|\left\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle-\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle\right|\\ &\leq\frac{1}{1+\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle}\max\left({\left\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle,\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle}\right)\\ &\leq\frac{1}{1+C_{1}}\max\left({\left\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\right\rangle,C_{1}}\right),\end{split} (29)

where the first inequality is from the fact that both ⟨𝒑,𝒓(t)⟩𝒑superscript𝒓𝑡\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle and ⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle are nonnegative, and the second inequality is due to the minimized denominator achieving the upper bound. Since ⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle can achieve its maximum as C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}, we can further bound as follows.

11+C1​max⁡(⟨𝒒,𝒓(t)⟩,C1)≤11+C1​max⁡(C2,C1)=C21+C111subscript𝐶1𝒒superscript𝒓𝑡subscript𝐶111subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶21subscript𝐶1\begin{gathered}\frac{1}{1+C_{1}}\max({\langle\boldsymbol{q},\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}\rangle,C_{1}})\leq\frac{1}{1+C_{1}}\max({C_{2},C_{1}})=\frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}}\end{gathered} (30)

Finally, using the fact that ‖𝒑−𝒒‖∞=maxi⁡|pi−qi|=1subscriptnorm𝒑𝒒subscript𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑞𝑖1\|\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{q}\|_{\infty}=\max_{i}|p_{i}-q_{i}|=1, we can conclude the statement by setting L∞=C21+C1subscript𝐿subscript𝐶21subscript𝐶1L_{\infty}=\frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}}. ∎

A.2.3 Unbiasedness of Doubly Robust Estimator (Lemma 4.3)

Proof.

Denote the client sampling probability C∈[0,1]𝐶01C\in[0,1] in time t𝑡t as P​(i∈S(t))=C𝑃𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶P(i\in S^{(t)})=C. Taking expectation on the doubly robust estimator of partially observed response defined in (10), we have

𝔼​[r˘i(t)]=𝔼​[(1−𝕀​(i∈S(t))C)​r¯(t)]+𝔼​[𝕀​(i∈S(t))C​ri(t)]=(1−𝔼​[𝕀​(i∈S(t))]C)​r¯(t)+𝔼​[𝕀​(i∈S(t))]C​ri(t)=(1−P​(i∈S(t))C)​r¯(t)+P​(i∈S(t))C​ri(t)=ri(t),𝔼delimited-[]subscriptsuperscript˘𝑟𝑡𝑖𝔼delimited-[]1𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶superscript¯r𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖1𝔼delimited-[]𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶superscript¯r𝑡𝔼delimited-[]𝕀𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖1𝑃𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶superscript¯r𝑡𝑃𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡𝐶subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑟𝑡𝑖\begin{split}&\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{r}^{(t)}_{i}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\bigg{(}1-\frac{\mathbb{I}(i\in S^{(t)})}{C}\bigg{)}\mathrm{\bar{r}}^{(t)}\right]+\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{\mathbb{I}(i\in S^{(t)})}{C}{r}^{(t)}_{i}\right]\\ &=\bigg{(}1-\frac{\mathbb{E}[\mathbb{I}(i\in S^{(t)})]}{C}\bigg{)}\mathrm{\bar{r}}^{(t)}+\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\mathbb{I}(i\in S^{(t)})\right]}{C}{r}^{(t)}_{i}\\ &=\bigg{(}1-\frac{P(i\in S^{(t)})}{C}\bigg{)}\mathrm{\bar{r}}^{(t)}+\frac{P(i\in S^{(t)})}{C}{r}^{(t)}_{i}\\ &={r}^{(t)}_{i},\end{split} (31)

where 𝕀​(⋅)𝕀⋅\mathbb{I}(\cdot) is an indicator function.

Note that the randomness of the doubly robust estimator comes from the random sampling of client indices i∈S(t)𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡i\in S^{(t)} in round t𝑡t, thus the expectation is with respect to i∈S(t)𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡i\in S^{(t)}. Thus, we can conclude that 𝔼​[𝒓˘(t)]=𝒓(t)𝔼delimited-[]superscript˘𝒓𝑡superscript𝒓𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}^{(t)}\right]=\boldsymbol{r}^{(t)}. See also (Robins et al., 1994; Bang & Robins, 2005). ∎

A.2.4 Unbiasedness of Linearly Approximated Gradient (Lemma 4.4)

Proof.

The gradient of a decision loss in terms of a response, 𝒈≡𝐡​(𝒓)=[h1​(𝒓),…,hK​(𝒓)]⊤=−𝒓1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩𝒈𝐡𝒓superscriptsubscriptℎ1𝒓…subscriptℎ𝐾𝒓top𝒓1𝒑𝒓\boldsymbol{g}\equiv\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}(\boldsymbol{r})=[h_{1}(\boldsymbol{r}),...,h_{K}(\boldsymbol{r})]^{\top}=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle} can be linearly approximated at reference 𝒓0subscript𝒓0\boldsymbol{r}_{0} as follows.

𝐡~​(𝒓)=𝐡​(𝒓0)+𝐉𝐡​(𝒓0)​(𝒓−𝒓0)~𝐡𝒓𝐡subscript𝒓0subscript𝐉𝐡subscript𝒓0𝒓subscript𝒓0\begin{gathered}\tilde{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r})={\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r}_{0})+\mathrm{\mathbf{J}}_{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r}_{0})(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}_{0})\end{gathered} (32)

The Jacobian 𝐉𝐡​(𝒓)∈ℝK×Ksubscript𝐉𝐡𝒓superscriptℝ𝐾𝐾\mathrm{\mathbf{J}}_{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r})\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K} is defined as follows.

𝐉𝐡​(𝒓)=[∂𝐡∂r1,…,∂𝐡∂rK]=[∂h1∂r1⋯∂h1∂rK⋮⋱⋮∂hK∂r1⋯∂hK∂rK]=[−11+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩+p1​r1(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2p2​r1(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2⋯pK​r1(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2p1​r2(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2−11+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩+p2​r2(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2⋯pK​r2(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2⋮⋮⋱⋮p1​rK(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2p2​rK(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2⋯−11+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩+pK​rK(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2]=−11+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩​𝑰K+1(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓⟩)2​𝒓​𝒑⊤subscript𝐉𝐡𝒓𝐡subscript𝑟1…𝐡subscript𝑟𝐾delimited-[]subscriptℎ1subscript𝑟1⋯subscriptℎ1subscript𝑟𝐾⋮⋱⋮subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝑟1⋯subscriptℎ𝐾subscript𝑟𝐾delimited-[]11𝒑𝒓subscript𝑝1subscript𝑟1superscript1𝒑𝒓2subscript𝑝2subscript𝑟1superscript1𝒑𝒓2⋯subscript𝑝𝐾subscript𝑟1superscript1𝒑𝒓2subscript𝑝1subscript𝑟2superscript1𝒑𝒓211𝒑𝒓subscript𝑝2subscript𝑟2superscript1𝒑𝒓2⋯subscript𝑝𝐾subscript𝑟2superscript1𝒑𝒓2⋮⋮⋱⋮subscript𝑝1subscript𝑟𝐾superscript1𝒑𝒓2subscript𝑝2subscript𝑟𝐾superscript1𝒑𝒓2⋯11𝒑𝒓subscript𝑝𝐾subscript𝑟𝐾superscript1𝒑𝒓211𝒑𝒓subscript𝑰𝐾1superscript1𝒑𝒓2𝒓superscript𝒑top\begin{split}\mathrm{\mathbf{J}}_{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\boldsymbol{r})&=\left[\frac{\partial\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}{\partial r_{1}},...,\frac{\partial\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}{\partial r_{K}}\right]\\ &=\left[\begin{array}[]{ccc}\frac{\partial h_{1}}{\partial r_{1}}&\cdots&\frac{\partial h_{1}}{\partial r_{K}}\\ \vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \frac{\partial h_{K}}{\partial r_{1}}&\cdots&\frac{\partial h_{K}}{\partial r_{K}}\end{array}\right]\\ &=\left[\begin{array}[]{cccc}-\frac{1}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle}+\frac{p_{1}r_{1}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}&\frac{p_{2}r_{1}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}&\cdots&\frac{p_{K}r_{1}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}\\ \vdots&\vdots&\ddots&\vdots\\ \frac{p_{1}r_{K}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}&\frac{p_{2}r_{K}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}&\cdots&-\frac{1}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle}+\frac{p_{K}r_{K}}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}\end{array}\right]\\ &=-\frac{1}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle}\boldsymbol{I}_{K}+\frac{1}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}\rangle)^{2}}\boldsymbol{r}\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}\end{split} (33)

Plugging (33) into (32) with respect to arbitrary reference 𝒓0subscript𝒓0\boldsymbol{r}_{0}, we have a linearized gradient of a decision loss as follows.

From the statement of Lemma 4.4, plugging the doubly robust estimator of the partially observed response, 𝒓˘˘𝒓\breve{\boldsymbol{r}} from Lemma 4.3 into above, we have gradient estimate 𝒈˘˘𝒈\breve{\boldsymbol{g}} as follows.

Taking an expectation, we have

𝔼​[𝒈˘]=𝔼​[𝐡~​(𝒓˘)]=−𝔼​[𝒓˘]1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩+𝒓0​𝒑⊤​(𝔼​[𝒓˘]−𝒓0)(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩)2=−𝒓1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩+𝒓0​𝒑⊤​(𝒓−𝒓0)(1+⟨𝒑,𝒓0⟩)2=𝐡~​(𝒓)=𝒈~≈𝒈.𝔼delimited-[]˘𝒈𝔼delimited-[]~𝐡˘𝒓𝔼delimited-[]˘𝒓1𝒑subscript𝒓0subscript𝒓0superscript𝒑top𝔼delimited-[]˘𝒓subscript𝒓0superscript1𝒑subscript𝒓02𝒓1𝒑subscript𝒓0subscript𝒓0superscript𝒑top𝒓subscript𝒓0superscript1𝒑subscript𝒓02~𝐡𝒓~𝒈𝒈\begin{gathered}\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}\right]=\mathbb{E}\left[\tilde{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}(\breve{\boldsymbol{r}})\right]=-\frac{\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}\right]}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\rangle}+\frac{\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}(\mathbb{E}\left[\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}\right]-\boldsymbol{r}_{0})}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\rangle)^{2}}=-\frac{\boldsymbol{r}}{1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\rangle}+\frac{\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}(\boldsymbol{r}-\boldsymbol{r}_{0})}{(1+\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{r}_{0}\rangle)^{2}}\\ =\tilde{\mathrm{\mathbf{h}}}({\boldsymbol{r}})=\tilde{\boldsymbol{g}}\approx\boldsymbol{g}.\end{gathered} (36)

∎

For each case, ‖𝒓˘‖∞subscriptnorm˘𝒓\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}\right\|_{\infty} becomes

‖𝒓˘‖∞={r¯,i∉S(t)supi|1C​(ri−r¯)+r¯|,i∈S(t).subscriptdelimited-∥∥˘𝒓cases¯r𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscriptsupremum𝑖1𝐶subscript𝑟𝑖¯r¯r𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\begin{split}&\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}\right\|_{\infty}=\begin{cases}\bar{\mathrm{r}},&i\notin S^{(t)}\\ \sup_{i}\left|\frac{1}{C}(r_{i}-\bar{\mathrm{r}})+\bar{\mathrm{r}}\right|,&i\in S^{(t)}.\end{cases}\end{split} (41)

For the first case, the average is smaller than its maximum, thus r¯≤C2¯rsubscript𝐶2\bar{\mathrm{r}}\leq C_{2}. For the second case, it can be upper bounded as supi|1C​(ri−r¯)+r¯|≤1C​supi|ri−r¯|+C2subscriptsupremum𝑖1𝐶subscript𝑟𝑖¯r¯r1𝐶subscriptsupremum𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖¯rsubscript𝐶2\sup_{i}\left|\frac{1}{C}(r_{i}-\bar{\mathrm{r}})+\bar{\mathrm{r}}\right|\leq\frac{1}{C}\sup_{i}\left|r_{i}-\bar{\mathrm{r}}\right|+C_{2} by the triangle inequality.

From the trivial fact that the deviation from the average is always smaller than its range,

1C​supi|ri−r¯|≤1C​(C2−C1).1𝐶subscriptsupremum𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖¯r1𝐶subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1\begin{gathered}\frac{1}{C}\sup_{i}\left|r_{i}-\bar{\mathrm{r}}\right|\leq\frac{1}{C}(C_{2}-C_{1}).\end{gathered} (42)

Combined, we have the following upper bounds.

‖𝒓˘‖∞≤{C2,i∉S(t)C2−C1C+C2,i∈S(t)subscriptdelimited-∥∥˘𝒓casessubscript𝐶2𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1𝐶subscript𝐶2𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\begin{split}\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\begin{cases}C_{2},&i\notin S^{(t)}\\ \frac{C_{2}-C_{1}}{C}+C_{2},&i\in S^{(t)}\end{cases}\end{split} (43)

Similarly, for the second term inside in (39), we have:

‖𝒓˘−𝒓¯‖∞={0,i∉S(t)1C​supi|ri−r¯|,i∈S(t).subscriptdelimited-∥∥˘𝒓¯𝒓cases0𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡1𝐶subscriptsupremum𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖¯r𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\begin{split}&\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}-\bar{\boldsymbol{r}}\right\|_{\infty}=\begin{cases}0,&i\notin S^{(t)}\\ \frac{1}{C}\sup_{i}\left|r_{i}-\bar{\mathrm{r}}\right|,&i\in S^{(t)}.\end{cases}\end{split} (44)

Corresponding upper bounds are:

‖𝒓˘−𝒓¯‖∞≤{0,i∉S(t)C2−C1C,i∈S(t)subscriptdelimited-∥∥˘𝒓¯𝒓cases0𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1𝐶𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\begin{gathered}\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{r}}-\bar{\boldsymbol{r}}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\begin{cases}0,&i\notin S^{(t)}\\ \frac{C_{2}-C_{1}}{C},&i\in S^{(t)}\end{cases}\end{gathered} (45)

Finally, adding (43) and (45) to have (39), we have:

‖𝒈˘(t)‖∞≤{C21+C1,i∉S(t)C21+C1+2​(C2−C1)C​(1+C1),i∈S(t).subscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript˘𝒈𝑡casessubscript𝐶21subscript𝐶1𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝐶21subscript𝐶12subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1𝐶1subscript𝐶1𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\begin{gathered}\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\begin{cases}\frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}},&i\notin S^{(t)}\\ \frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}}+\frac{2(C_{2}-C_{1})}{C(1+C_{1})},&i\in S^{(t)}.\end{cases}\end{gathered} (46)

Finally, it suffices to set L˘∞=C21+C1+2​(C2−C1)C​(1+C1)subscript˘𝐿subscript𝐶21subscript𝐶12subscript𝐶2subscript𝐶1𝐶1subscript𝐶1\breve{L}_{\infty}=\frac{C_{2}}{1+C_{1}}+\frac{2(C_{2}-C_{1})}{C(1+C_{1})} to conclude the proof. ∎

A.2.6 Regret from a Linearized Loss

Corollary A.3.

From the convexity of a decision loss ℓ(t)superscriptℓ𝑡\ell^{(t)} (Lemma A.1), the regret defined in (5) satisfies

Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)=∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝐩(t))−∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝐩⋆)≤∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝐩(t))−∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝐩⋆),superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptℓtsuperscript𝐩tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptℓtsuperscript𝐩⋆superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~ℓtsuperscript𝐩tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~ℓtsuperscript𝐩⋆\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right),\end{gathered} (47)

where ℓ~(t)superscript~ℓ𝑡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)} is a linearized loss defined as ℓ~(t)​(𝐩)=⟨𝐩,𝐠(t)⟩superscript~ℓ𝑡𝐩𝐩superscript𝐠𝑡\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\rangle and 𝐠(t)=∇ℓ(t)​(𝐩(t))superscript𝐠𝑡∇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝐩𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right).

Proof.

It is straightforward from the convexity of the decision loss.

ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))−ℓ(t)​(𝒑⋆)≤⟨𝒈(t),𝒑(t)−𝒑⋆⟩.superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑⋆superscript𝒈𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝒑⋆\begin{gathered}\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)})-\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star})\leq\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)},\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}-\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right\rangle.\end{gathered} (48)

Summing up both sides for t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], we proved the statement. ∎

A.2.7 Equality for the Regret

A.2.8 Upper Bound to the Suboptimality Gap

Lemma A.5.

(Oracle Gap; Corollary 7.7 of (Orabona, 2019)) Let f:ℝK→ℝ:𝑓→superscriptℝ𝐾ℝf:\mathbb{R}^{K}\rightarrow\mathbb{R} be a μ𝜇\mu-strongly convex w.r.t. ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| over its domain. Let 𝐱⋆=arg​min𝐱⁡f​(𝐱)superscript𝐱⋆subscriptargmin𝐱𝑓𝐱\boldsymbol{x}^{\star}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{x}}f(\boldsymbol{x}). Then, for all 𝐱∈dom​∂f​(𝐱)𝐱dom𝑓𝐱\boldsymbol{x}\in\operatorname{dom}\partial f(\boldsymbol{x}), and 𝐠∈∂f​(𝐱)𝐠𝑓𝐱\boldsymbol{g}\in\partial f(\boldsymbol{x}), we have:

f​(𝒙)−f​(𝒙⋆)≤12​μ​‖𝒈‖⋆2,𝑓𝒙𝑓superscript𝒙⋆12𝜇superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒈⋆2\begin{gathered}f(\boldsymbol{x})-f(\boldsymbol{x}^{\star})\leq\frac{1}{2\mu}\|\boldsymbol{g}\|_{\star}^{2},\end{gathered} (57)

where ∥⋅∥⋆\|\cdot\|_{\star} is a dual norm of ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|.

A.2.9 Progress Bound

Lemma A.6.

(Progress Bound of FTRL with Proximal Regularizer) With a slight abuse of notation, assume L(t)superscript𝐿𝑡L^{(t)} is closed, subdifferentiable and μ(t)superscript𝜇𝑡\mu^{(t)}-strongly convex w.r.t. ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\| in ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1}. First assume that 𝐩(t+1)=arg​min𝐩∈ΔK−1⁡L(t+1)​(𝐩)superscript𝐩𝑡1subscriptargmin𝐩subscriptΔ𝐾1superscript𝐿𝑡1𝐩\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right). Assume further that the regularizer satisfies 𝐩(t)=arg​min𝐩∈ΔK−1⁡(R(t+1)​(𝐩)−R(t)​(𝐩))superscript𝐩𝑡subscriptargmin𝐩subscriptΔ𝐾1superscript𝑅𝑡1𝐩superscript𝑅𝑡𝐩\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left(R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)-R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\right), and 𝐠(t)∈∂L(t+1)​(𝐩(t))superscript𝐠𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝐩𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\in\partial L^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}). Then, we have the following inequality:

L(t)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))≤‖𝒈(t)‖⋆22​μ(t+1)+(R(t)​(𝒑(t))−R(t+1)​(𝒑(t))),superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡⋆22superscript𝜇𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡\begin{gathered}L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\leq\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\|_{\star}^{2}}{2\mu^{(t+1)}}+\left(R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\right),\end{gathered} (58)

where ∥⋅∥⋆\|\cdot\|_{\star} is a dual norm of ∥⋅∥\|\cdot\|.

Proof.
L(t)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))=(L(t)​(𝒑(t))+ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))+R(t+1)​(𝒑(t))−R(t)​(𝒑(t)))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))−R(t+1)​(𝒑(t))+R(t)​(𝒑(t))=L(t+1)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))−R(t+1)​(𝒑(t))+R(t)​(𝒑(t))≤‖𝒈(t)‖⋆22​μ(t+1)−R(t+1)​(𝒑(t))+R(t)​(𝒑(t)),superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡⋆22superscript𝜇𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\begin{split}&L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\\ &=\left(L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)+\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)+R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\right)-L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)+R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\\ &=L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)+R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\\ &\leq\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\|_{\star}^{2}}{2\mu^{(t+1)}}-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)+R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right),\end{split} (59)

where the first inequality is due the assumption that 𝒑(t+1)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡L(t+1)​(𝒑)superscript𝒑𝑡1subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscript𝐿𝑡1𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right), 𝒈(t)∈∂L(t+1)​(𝒑(t))superscript𝒈𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\in\partial L^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}), and the result from Lemma A.5. See also Lemma 7.23 of (Orabona, 2019). ∎

Lemma A.7.

(Progress Bound of FTRL with Non-Decreasing Regularizer) With a slight abuse of notation, assume L(t)superscript𝐿𝑡L^{(t)} to be closed and sub-differentiable in ΔKsubscriptΔ𝐾\Delta_{K}, and (L(t)+ℓ(t))superscript𝐿𝑡superscriptℓ𝑡\left(L^{(t)}+\ell^{(t)}\right) to be closed, differentiable and ν(t)superscript𝜈𝑡\nu^{(t)}-strongly convex w.r.t. ∥⋅∥1\|\cdot\|_{1} in ΔK−1subscriptΔ𝐾1\Delta_{K-1}. Then, we have the following inequality:

L(t)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))≤‖𝒈(t)‖∞22​ν(t)+(R(t)​(𝒑(t+1))−R(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))).superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡22superscript𝜈𝑡superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1\begin{gathered}L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\leq\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}}{2\nu^{(t)}}+\left(R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)\right).\end{gathered} (60)
Proof.

L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))=L(t)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t+1))−R(t)​(𝒑(t+1))+R(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1)),superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡1superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript𝑅𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1\begin{gathered}L^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)=L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)-R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right),\end{gathered} (61)

we have
