&\leq\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}}{2\nu^{(t)}}+\left(R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)-R^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)\right),\end{split} (62)

where the first inequality is due the assumption that 𝒑∗(t)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡(L(t)+ℓ(t))⁡(𝒑)subscriptsuperscript𝒑𝑡subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscript𝐿𝑡superscriptℓ𝑡𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}_{*}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left(L^{(t)}+\ell^{(t)}\right)\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right), 𝒈(t)∈∂(L(t)+ℓ(t))superscript𝒈𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡superscriptℓ𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\in\partial\left(L^{(t)}+\ell^{(t)}\right). Lastly, the second inequality is the direct result from Lemma A.5. See also Lemma 7.8 of (Orabona, 2019). ∎

A.2.10 Exp-concavity

Definition A.8.

A function f:X→ℝ:𝑓→𝑋ℝf:X\rightarrow\mathbb{R} is γ𝛾\gamma-exp-concave if exp⁡(−γ​f​(𝒙))𝛾𝑓𝒙\exp\left(-\gamma f\left(\boldsymbol{x}\right)\right) is concave for 𝒙∈X𝒙𝑋\boldsymbol{x}\in X.

Remark A.9.

The decision loss defined in (4) is 111-exp-concave.

Lemma A.10.

For an γ𝛾\gamma-exp-concave function f:X→ℝ:𝑓→𝑋ℝf:X\rightarrow\mathbb{R}, let the domain X𝑋X is bounded, and choose δ≤γ2𝛿𝛾2\delta\leq\frac{\gamma}{2} such that |δ​⟨∇f​(𝐱),𝐲−𝐱⟩|≤12𝛿∇𝑓𝐱𝐲𝐱12\left|\delta\left\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}),\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\right\rangle\right|\leq\frac{1}{2} and for all 𝐱,𝐲∈X𝐱𝐲𝑋\boldsymbol{x},\boldsymbol{y}\in X, the following statement holds.

f​(𝒚)≥f​(𝒙)+⟨∇f​(𝒙),𝒚−𝒙⟩+δ2​(⟨∇f​(𝒚),𝒚−𝒙⟩)2𝑓𝒚𝑓𝒙∇𝑓𝒙𝒚𝒙𝛿2superscript∇𝑓𝒚𝒚𝒙2\begin{gathered}f(\boldsymbol{y})\geq f(\boldsymbol{x})+\left\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}),\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\right\rangle+\frac{\delta}{2}\left(\left\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y}),\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\right\rangle\right)^{2}\end{gathered} (63)
Proof.

For all such that δ≤γ2𝛿𝛾2\delta\leq\frac{\gamma}{2}, a function g​(𝒙)=exp⁡(−2​δ​f​(𝒙))𝑔𝒙2𝛿𝑓𝒙g(\boldsymbol{x})=\exp\left(-2\delta f(\boldsymbol{x})\right) is concave. From the concavity of g𝑔g, we have:

g​(𝒙)≤g​(𝒚)+⟨∇g​(𝒚),𝒙−𝒚⟩.𝑔𝒙𝑔𝒚∇𝑔𝒚𝒙𝒚\begin{gathered}g(\boldsymbol{x})\leq g(\boldsymbol{y})+\left\langle\nabla g(\boldsymbol{y}),\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\right\rangle.\end{gathered} (64)

By taking logarithm on both sides, we have:

f​(𝒙)≥f​(𝒚)−12​δ​log⁡(1−2​δ​⟨∇f​(𝒚),𝒙−𝒚⟩).𝑓𝒙𝑓𝒚12𝛿12𝛿∇𝑓𝒚𝒙𝒚\begin{gathered}f(\boldsymbol{x})\geq f(\boldsymbol{y})-\frac{1}{2\delta}\log\left(1-2\delta\left\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{y}),\boldsymbol{x}-\boldsymbol{y}\right\rangle\right).\end{gathered} (65)

From the assumption, we have |δ​⟨∇f​(𝒙),𝒚−𝒙⟩|≤12𝛿∇𝑓𝒙𝒚𝒙12\left|\delta\left\langle\nabla f(\boldsymbol{x}),\boldsymbol{y}-\boldsymbol{x}\right\rangle\right|\leq\frac{1}{2}, and using the fact that log⁡(1+x)≤x−x241𝑥𝑥superscript𝑥24\log(1+x)\leq x-\frac{x^{2}}{4} for |x|≤1𝑥1|x|\leq 1, we can conclude the proof. ∎

Remark A.11.

(Remark 7.27 from (Orabona, 2019)) For a positive definite matrix 𝑩∈ℝK×K𝑩superscriptℝ𝐾𝐾\boldsymbol{B}\in\mathbb{R}^{K\times K}, ‖𝒑‖𝑩subscriptnorm𝒑𝑩\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{\boldsymbol{B}} is a norm induced by 𝑩𝑩\boldsymbol{B}, defined as ‖𝒑‖𝑩≜𝒑⊤​𝑩​𝒑≜subscriptnorm𝒑𝑩superscript𝒑top𝑩𝒑\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{\boldsymbol{B}}\triangleq\sqrt{\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}\boldsymbol{B}\boldsymbol{p}} for 𝒑∈ℝK𝒑superscriptℝ𝐾\boldsymbol{p}\in\mathbb{R}^{K}. A function f​(𝒑)=12​𝒑⊤​𝑩​𝒑𝑓𝒑12superscript𝒑top𝑩𝒑f(\boldsymbol{p})=\frac{1}{2}\boldsymbol{p}^{\top}\boldsymbol{B}\boldsymbol{p} is therefore 111-strongly convex w.r.t. ∥⋅∥𝑩\|\cdot\|_{\boldsymbol{B}}. Note that the dual norm of ∥⋅∥𝑩\|\cdot\|_{\boldsymbol{B}} is ∥⋅∥𝑩−1\|\cdot\|_{\boldsymbol{B}^{-1}}.

A.3 Regret Bound of AAggFF-S: Proof of Theorem 5.1

Remark A.12.

The regularizer of AAggFF-S (i.e., ONS) is proximal since it has a quadratic form.

Proof.

Since Lemma A.4 holds for arbitrary loss function, let us set L(t)​(𝒑)≜∑τ=1t−1ℓ~(τ)​(𝒑)+α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t−1(⟨𝒈(τ),𝒑−𝒑(τ)⟩)2≜superscript𝐿𝑡𝒑superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscript~ℓ𝜏𝒑𝛼2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝒑𝜏2{L}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\triangleq\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}(\boldsymbol{p})+\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2} as in (7) with a slight abuse of notation. Note that we set R(t)​(𝒑)=α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t−1(⟨𝒈(τ),𝒑−𝒑(τ)⟩)2superscript𝑅𝑡𝒑𝛼2superscriptsubscriptnorm𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝒑𝜏2R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2}, which is often called a proximal regularizer.

From the regret, we have:

Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)=∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))−∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝒑⋆)≤∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝒑(t))−∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝒑⋆)=R(T+1)​(𝒑⋆)−R(1)​(𝒑(1))⏟(i)+L(T+1)​(𝒑(T+1))−L(T+1)​(𝒑⋆)⏟(ii)+∑t=1T[L(t)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ~(t)​(𝒑(t))]⏟(iii)superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑⋆superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript~ℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscript~ℓ𝑡superscript𝒑⋆subscript⏟superscript𝑅𝑇1superscript𝒑⋆superscript𝑅1superscript𝒑1(i)subscript⏟superscript𝐿𝑇1superscript𝒑𝑇1superscript𝐿𝑇1superscript𝒑⋆(ii)subscript⏟superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇delimited-[]superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript~ℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡(iii)\begin{split}&\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\\ &=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\\ &\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\\ &=\underbrace{R^{(T+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)-R^{(1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(1)}\right)}_{\text{(i)}}+\underbrace{{L}^{(T+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(T+1)}\right)-{L}^{(T+1)}\left({\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}}\right)}_{\text{(ii)}}\\ &+\underbrace{\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left[{L}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-{L}^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\right]}_{\text{(iii)}}\end{split} (66)

Let us first denote 𝑨(t)≜𝒈(t)​𝒈(t)⊤≜superscript𝑨𝑡superscript𝒈𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝑡top\boldsymbol{A}^{(t)}\triangleq\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}{\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}}^{\top} for 𝒈(t)=∇ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))superscript𝒈𝑡∇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}) as in the main text, and further denote that 𝑩(t)≜α​𝑰K+β​∑τ=1t𝑨(τ)≜superscript𝑩𝑡𝛼subscript𝑰𝐾𝛽superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript𝑨𝜏\boldsymbol{B}^{(t)}\triangleq\alpha\boldsymbol{I}_{K}+\beta\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\boldsymbol{A}^{(\tau)}. Then, we can rewrite the regularizer of AAggFF-D as follows.

R(t)​(𝒑)=α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t−1(⟨𝒈(τ),𝒑−𝒑(τ)⟩)2=α2​‖𝒑‖22+β2​∑τ=1t−1‖𝒑(τ)−𝒑‖𝑨(τ)2superscript𝑅𝑡𝒑𝛼2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscriptsuperscript𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝒑𝜏2𝛼2superscriptsubscriptdelimited-∥∥𝒑22𝛽2superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1subscriptsuperscriptdelimited-∥∥superscript𝒑𝜏𝒑2superscript𝑨𝜏\begin{gathered}R^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)=\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left(\left\langle\boldsymbol{g}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}-\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle\right)^{2}=\frac{\alpha}{2}\|\boldsymbol{p}\|_{2}^{2}+\frac{\beta}{2}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\left\|\boldsymbol{p}^{(\tau)}-\boldsymbol{p}\right\|^{2}_{\boldsymbol{A}^{(\tau)}}\end{gathered} (67)

A.4 Regret Bound of AAggFF-D with Full Client Participation: Proof of Theorem 5.2

Proof.

Again, since Lemma A.4 holds for arbitrary loss function, let us set L(t)​(𝒑)≜∑τ=1t−1ℓ~(τ)​(𝒑)+η(t+1)​∑i=1Kpi​log⁡pi≜superscript𝐿𝑡𝒑superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscript~ℓ𝜏𝒑superscript𝜂𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖{L}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\triangleq\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}(\boldsymbol{p})+\eta^{(t+1)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i} with a slight abuse of notation. For (i), recall from Lemma A.4 that the regret does not depend on the regularizer, we can bound it after changing from R(T+1)​(𝒑⋆)superscript𝑅𝑇1superscript𝒑⋆R^{(T+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right) to R(T)​(𝒑⋆)superscript𝑅𝑇superscript𝒑⋆R^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right).

R(T)​(𝒑⋆)−R(1)​(𝒑)≤η(T)​∑i=1Kpi⋆​log⁡pi⋆+η(1)​log⁡K≤η(T)​∑i=1Kpi⋆​log⁡pi⋆+η(T)​log⁡K≤η(T)​log⁡K.superscript𝑅𝑇superscript𝒑⋆superscript𝑅1𝒑superscript𝜂𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖⋆superscript𝜂1𝐾superscript𝜂𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖⋆superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖⋆superscript𝜂𝑇𝐾superscript𝜂𝑇𝐾\begin{gathered}R^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)-R^{(1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right)\leq\eta^{(T)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}{p_{i}^{\star}\log p_{i}^{\star}}+\eta^{(1)}\log{K}\leq\eta^{(T)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}{p_{i}^{\star}\log p_{i}^{\star}}+\eta^{(T)}\log{K}\leq\eta^{(T)}\log{K}.\end{gathered} (83)

For (ii), we use the assumption in Lemma A.7, where 𝒑(t)=arg​min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡L(t)​(𝒑)superscript𝒑𝑡subscriptargmin𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscript𝐿𝑡𝒑\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}=\operatorname*{arg\,min}_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}L^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}\right). From the assumption, since 𝒑(T+1)superscript𝒑𝑇1\boldsymbol{p}^{(T+1)} is the minimizer of L(T+1)superscript𝐿𝑇1L^{(T+1)}, (ii) becomes negative. Thus, we can exclude it from the upper bound.

For (iii), we directly use the result of Lemma A.7 as follows.

∑t=1T[L(t)​(𝒑(t))−L(t+1)​(𝒑(t+1))+ℓ~(t)​(𝒑(t))]≤∑t=1T‖𝒈(t)‖∞22​η(t)≤∑t=1TL∞22​η(t),superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇delimited-[]superscript𝐿𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscript𝐿𝑡1superscript𝒑𝑡1superscript~ℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscript𝒈𝑡22superscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝐿22superscript𝜂𝑡\begin{gathered}\sum_{t=1}^{T}\left[{L}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-{L}^{(t+1)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}\right)+\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)\right]\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{\left\|\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}^{2}}{2\eta^{(t)}}\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{L_{\infty}^{2}}{2\eta^{(t)}},\end{gathered} (84)

where the additional terms are removed due to the non-decreasing property of regularizer thanks to the assumption of η(t)superscript𝜂𝑡\eta^{(t)}, and the last inequality is due to Lemma 4.1. Note that 𝒈(t)=∇ℓ(t)​(𝒑(t))superscript𝒈𝑡∇superscriptℓ𝑡superscript𝒑𝑡\boldsymbol{g}^{(t)}=\nabla\ell^{(t)}(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}).

Combining all, we have regret upper bound as follows.

Regret(T)​(𝐩⋆)=∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝐩(t))−∑t=1Tℓ(t)​(𝐩⋆)≤∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝐩(t))−∑t=1Tℓ~(t)​(𝐩⋆)≤η(T)​log⁡K+∑t=1TL∞22​η(t).superscriptRegretTsuperscript𝐩⋆superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptℓtsuperscript𝐩tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscriptℓtsuperscript𝐩⋆superscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~ℓtsuperscript𝐩tsuperscriptsubscriptt1Tsuperscript~ℓtsuperscript𝐩⋆superscript𝜂TKsuperscriptsubscriptt1TsuperscriptsubscriptL22superscript𝜂t\begin{gathered}\text{Regret}^{(T)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)=\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\ell^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{(t)}\right)-\sum_{t=1}^{T}\tilde{\ell}^{(t)}\left(\boldsymbol{p}^{\star}\right)\leq\eta^{(T)}\log{K}+\sum_{t=1}^{T}\frac{L_{\infty}^{2}}{2\eta^{(t)}}.\end{gathered} (85)

Finally, by setting η(t)=L∞​tlog⁡Ksuperscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐿𝑡𝐾\eta^{(t)}=\frac{L_{\infty}\sqrt{t}}{\sqrt{\log{K}}}, we have

A.5 Regret Bound of AAggFF-D with Partial Client Participation: Proof of Corollary 5.3

Remark A.13.

Even though we can enjoy the same regret upper bound in expectation from Corollary 5.3, it should be noted that the raw regret (i.e., regret without expectation) from 𝒈˘(t)superscript˘𝒈𝑡\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)} may inflate the regret upper bound from 𝒪​(L∞​K​T​log⁡K)𝒪subscript𝐿𝐾𝑇𝐾\mathcal{O}\left(L_{\infty}K\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right) to 𝒪​(L˘∞​K​T​log⁡K)𝒪subscript˘𝐿𝐾𝑇𝐾\mathcal{O}\left(\breve{L}_{\infty}K\sqrt{T\log{K}}\right), where L˘∞subscript˘𝐿\breve{L}_{\infty} is a Lipschitz constant from Lemma A.2, upper bounding ‖𝒈˘(t)‖∞≤L˘∞subscriptnormsuperscript˘𝒈𝑡subscript˘𝐿\left\|\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}\right\|_{\infty}\leq\breve{L}_{\infty}. It is because L˘∞subscript˘𝐿\breve{L}_{\infty} is dominated by 1/C≈𝒪​(K)1𝐶𝒪𝐾{1}/{C}\approx\mathcal{O}\left(K\right), which can be a huge number when if C𝐶C is a tiny constant. Although this inflation hinders proper update of AAggFF-D empirically, this can be easily eliminated in AAggFF-D through an appropriate choice of a range (C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2}) of the response vector, which ensures practicality of AAggFF-D. See Appendix B.2 for a detail.

A.6 Derivation of Closed-From Update of AAggFF-D

The objective of AAggFF-D in (9) can be written in the following form.

min𝒑∈ΔK−1​∑τ=1tℓ~(τ)​(𝒑)+η(t+1)​∑i=1Kpi​log⁡pi=min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡⟨𝒑,∑τ=1t−1𝒈˘(τ)⟩+η(t+1)​∑i=1Kpi​log⁡pi=min𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡⟨∑τ=1t𝒈˘(τ),𝒑⟩+R(t+1)​(𝒑)=max𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡⟨−∑τ=1t𝒈˘(τ),𝒑⟩−R(t+1)​(𝒑).subscript𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript~ℓ𝜏𝒑superscript𝜂𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1𝒑superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡1superscript˘𝒈𝜏superscript𝜂𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝑝𝑖subscript𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript˘𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑subscript𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript˘𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑\begin{split}&\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\tilde{\ell}^{(\tau)}(\boldsymbol{p})+\eta^{(t+1)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i}=\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle\boldsymbol{p},\sum_{\tau=1}^{t-1}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)}\right\rangle+\eta^{(t+1)}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p_{i}\log p_{i}\\ &=\min_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle+R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p})=\max_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle-R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}).\end{split} (89)

It exactly corresponds to the form of the Fenchel conjugate R∗(t+1)subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑡1R^{(t+1)}_{*}, which is defined as follows.

R∗(t+1)​(𝒑)=max𝒑∈ΔK−1⁡⟨−∑τ=1t𝒈˘(τ),𝒑⟩−R(t+1)​(𝒑).subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑subscript𝒑subscriptΔ𝐾1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript˘𝒈𝜏𝒑superscript𝑅𝑡1𝒑\begin{gathered}R^{(t+1)}_{*}(\boldsymbol{p})=\max_{\boldsymbol{p}\in\Delta_{K-1}}\left\langle-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)},\boldsymbol{p}\right\rangle-R^{(t+1)}(\boldsymbol{p}).\end{gathered} (90)

Thus, we can enjoy the property of Fenchel conjugate, which is

𝒑(t+1)=∇R∗(t+1)​(−∑τ=1t𝒈˘(τ))superscript𝒑𝑡1∇subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡superscript˘𝒈𝜏\begin{gathered}\boldsymbol{p}^{(t+1)}=\nabla R^{(t+1)}_{*}\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(\tau)}\right)\end{gathered} (91)

Since we can derive the log-sum-exp form by solving (90) as follows,

R∗(t+1)​(𝒖)=log⁡(∑i=1Kexp⁡(ui)),subscriptsuperscript𝑅𝑡1𝒖superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscript𝑢𝑖\begin{gathered}R^{(t+1)}_{*}(\boldsymbol{u})=\log{\left(\sum_{i=1}^{K}\exp\left(u_{i}\right)\right)},\end{gathered} (92)

we have the closed-form solution for the new decision update.

pi(t+1)=exp⁡(−∑τ=1tg˘i(τ)/η(t+1))∑j=1Kexp⁡(−∑τ=1tg˘j(τ)/η(t+1)).subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡subscriptsuperscript˘𝑔𝜏𝑖superscript𝜂𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑗1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜏1𝑡subscriptsuperscript˘𝑔𝜏𝑗superscript𝜂𝑡1\begin{gathered}{p}^{(t+1)}_{i}=\frac{\exp\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{g}^{(\tau)}_{i}/\eta^{(t+1)}\right)}{\sum_{j=1}^{K}\exp\left(-\sum_{\tau=1}^{t}\breve{g}^{(\tau)}_{j}/\eta^{(t+1)}\right)}.\end{gathered} (93)

Note that η(t+1)superscript𝜂𝑡1\eta^{(t+1)} is already determined in Theorem 5.2 and Corollary 5.3 as L˘∞​t+1log⁡Ksubscript˘𝐿𝑡1𝐾\frac{\breve{L}_{\infty}\sqrt{t+1}}{\sqrt{\log{K}}}, with the reflection of modified Lipschitz constant from L∞subscript𝐿L_{\infty} to L˘∞subscript˘𝐿\breve{L}_{\infty} (see Remark A.13). See also (Helmbold et al., 1998) and Chapter 6.6 of (Orabona, 2019).

Appendix B Detailed Designs of AAggFF

B.1 Cumulative Distribution Function for Response Transformation

Choice of Distributions

We used the CDF to transform unbounded responses from clients (i.e., local losses of clients) into bounded values. Among diverse options, we used one of the following 6 CDFs in this work. (Note that erf⁡(x)=2π​∫0xe−y2​dyerf𝑥2𝜋superscriptsubscript0𝑥superscript𝑒superscript𝑦2differential-d𝑦\operatorname{erf}(x)=\frac{2}{\sqrt{\pi}}\int_{0}^{x}e^{-y^{2}}\mathrm{d}y is the Gauss error function)

  1. 1.

    Weibull (Weibull, 1951): CDF​(x)=1−e−(x/α)βCDF𝑥1superscript𝑒superscript𝑥𝛼𝛽\texttt{CDF}(x)=1-e^{-(x/\alpha)^{\beta}}; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale) and β=2𝛽2\beta=2 (shape).

  2. 2.

    Frechet (Fréchet, 1927): CDF​(x)=e−(xα)−βCDF𝑥superscript𝑒superscript𝑥𝛼𝛽\texttt{CDF}(x)=e^{-(\frac{x}{\alpha})^{-\beta}}; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale) and β=1𝛽1\beta=1 (shape).

  3. 3.

    Gumbel (Gumbel, 1935): CDF​(x)=e−e−(x−α)/βCDF𝑥superscript𝑒superscript𝑒𝑥𝛼𝛽\texttt{CDF}(x)=e^{-e^{-(x-\alpha)/\beta}}; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale) and β=1𝛽1\beta=1 (shape).

  4. 4.

    Exponential: CDF​(x)=1−e−α​xCDF𝑥1superscript𝑒𝛼𝑥\texttt{CDF}(x)=1-e^{-\alpha x}; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale).

  5. 5.

    Logistic: CDF​(x)=11+e(−(x−α)/β)CDF𝑥11superscript𝑒𝑥𝛼𝛽\texttt{CDF}(x)=\frac{1}{1+e^{(-(x-\alpha)/\beta)}}; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale) and β=1𝛽1\beta=1 (shape).

  6. 6.

    Normal (Gauß, 1809): CDF​(x)=12​[1+erf⁡(x−αβ​2)]CDF𝑥12delimited-[]1erf𝑥𝛼𝛽2\texttt{CDF}(x)=\frac{1}{2}\left[1+\operatorname{erf}\left(\frac{x-\alpha}{\beta\sqrt{2}}\right)\right]; we set α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 (scale) and β=1𝛽1\beta=1 (shape).

Commonly, the scale parameter of all distributions is set to 1, since in (8) we centered inputs to 1 in expectation. Although we fixed the parameters of each CDF, they can be statistically estimated in practice, such as using maximum spacing estimation (Cheng & Amin, 1983).

For imposing larger mixing coefficients for larger losses, the transformation should (i) preserve the relative difference between responses, as well as (ii) not too sensitive for outliers. While other heuristics (e.g., clipping values, subtracting from arbitrary large constant (Zhang et al., 2022)) for the transformation are also viable options for (i), additional efforts are still required to address (ii).

On the contrary, CDFs can address both conditions with ease. As CDFs are increasing functions, (i) can be easily satisfied. For (ii), it can be intrinsically addressed by the nature of CDF itself. Let us start with a simple example.

Suppose we have K=3𝐾3K=3 local losses: F1​(𝜽)=0.01,F2​(𝜽)=0.10,F3​(𝜽)=0.02formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹1𝜽0.01formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹2𝜽0.10subscript𝐹3𝜽0.02F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.01,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.02. Since the average is F¯=0.01+0.10+0.023≈0.043¯F0.010.100.0230.043\bar{\mathrm{F}}=\frac{0.01+0.10+0.02}{3}\approx 0.043, we have inputs of CDF as follows: F1​(𝜽)/F¯=0.23,F2​(𝜽)/F¯=2.31,F3​(𝜽)/F¯=0.46formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹1𝜽¯F0.23formulae-sequencesubscript𝐹2𝜽¯F2.31subscript𝐹3𝜽¯F0.46F_{1}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.23,F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=2.31,F_{3}(\boldsymbol{\theta})/\bar{\mathrm{F}}=0.46. These centered inputs are finally transformed into bounded values as in Table A1.

While all losses become bounded values in [0,1]01[0,1], the maximum local loss (i.e., F2​(𝜽)=0.10subscript𝐹2𝜽0.10F_{2}(\boldsymbol{\theta})=0.10) is transformed into different values by each CDF (see underlined figures in the ‘Transformed Responses’ column of Table A1). When using the Weibull CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 1.001.001.00, which means that there may be no value greater than 0.10 (i.e., 0.100.100.10 is the largest one in 100%percent100100\% probability) given current local losses. Meanwhile, when using the Frechet CDF, the maximum local loss is translated into 0.650.650.65, which means that there still is a 35% chance that some other local losses are greater than 0.100.100.10 when provided with other losses similar to 0.01 and 0.02. This implies that each CDF treats a maximum value differently. When a transformation is easily inclined to the maximum value, thereby returning 1 (i.e., maximum of CDF), it may yield a degenerate decision, e.g., 𝒑≈[0,1,0]⊤𝒑superscript010top\boldsymbol{p}\approx[0,1,0]^{\top}.

Fortunately, most of the listed CDFs are designed for modeling maximum values. For example, the three distributions, Gumbel, Frechet, and Weibull, are grouped as the Extreme Value Distribution (EVD) (Kotz & Nadarajah, 2000). As its name suggests, it models the behavior of extreme events, and it is well known that any density modeling a minimum or a maximum of independent and identically distributed (IID) samples follows the shape of one of these three distributions (by the Extreme Value Theorem (Rusnock & Kerr-Lawson, 2005)). In other words, EVDs can reasonably measure how a certain value is close to a maximum. Thus, they can estimate whether a certain value is relatively large or small. Otherwise, the Exponential distribution is a special case of Weibull distribution, and the logistic distribution is also related to the Gumbel distribution. Last but not least, although it is not a family of EVD, the Normal distribution is also considered due to the central limit theorem, since the local loss is the sum of errors from IID local samples. We expect the CDF transformation can appropriately measure a relative magnitude of local losses, and it should be helpful for decision making.

Effects of Response Transformation

We also illustrated that the response should be bounded (i.e., Lipschitz continuous) in section 4.2.1, to have non-vacuous regret upper bound. To acquire bounded response, we compare the cumulative values of a global objective in (1), i.e., ∑t=1T∑i=1Kpi(t)​Fi​(𝜽(t))superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝐾subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{i=1}^{K}p^{(t)}_{i}F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) for the cross-silo setting, and ∑t=1T∑i∈S(t)pi(t)​Fi​(𝜽(t))superscriptsubscript𝑡1𝑇subscript𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑡𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡\sum_{t=1}^{T}\sum_{i\in S^{(t)}}p^{(t)}_{i}F_{i}(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}) for the cross-device setting.

In the cross-silo experiment with the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF shows the smallest cumulative values, while in the cross-device experiment with the Reddit dataset, the Weibull CDF yields the smallest value. For the Berka dataset, the Normal CDF yields an average performance (AUROC) of 79.37 with the worst performance of 43.75, but the Weibull CDF shows an average performance of 73.02 with the worst performance of 25.00. The same tendency is also observed in the Reddit dataset. The Normal CDF presents an average performance (Acc. 1) of 14.05 and the worst performance of 4.26, while the Weibull CDF shows an average of 12.62 with the worst of 3.35. From these observations, we can conclude that an appropriate choice of CDF is necessary for better sequential decision making, and suitable transformation helps minimize a global objective of FL. Note also that these behaviors are also directly related to the global convergence of the algorithm w.r.t. 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}.

B.2 Choice of a Response Range

In regard to determining the range of a response vector, i.e., [C1,C2]subscript𝐶1subscript𝐶2[C_{1},C_{2}], we can refer to the Lipschitz continuity in Lemma 4.1 and Lemma A.2. For the cross-silo setting, we can set arbitrary constants so that L∞=𝒪​(1)subscript𝐿𝒪1L_{\infty}=\mathcal{O}(1) according to Lemma 4.1. Thus, for all experiments of AAggFF-S, we set C1=0,C2=1Kformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶10subscript𝐶21𝐾C_{1}=0,C_{2}=\frac{1}{K}.

For the cross-device setting, the Lipschitz constant is changed into L˘∞subscript˘𝐿\breve{L}_{\infty}, since it is influenced by the client sampling probability (C𝐶C). In detail, C𝐶C is located in the denominator of the Lipschitz constant, L˘∞subscript˘𝐿\breve{L}_{\infty}, which inflates the resulting gradient value as C𝐶C is a constant close to 0. (e.g., when 10 among 100,000 clients are participating in each round, 1/C=1041𝐶superscript104{1}/{C}=10^{4}) This is problematic and even causes an overflow problem empirically in updating a new decision. Thus, we propose a simple remedy — setting C1subscript𝐶1C_{1} and C2subscript𝐶2C_{2} to be a multiple of C𝐶C, so that the C𝐶C in the denominator is to be canceled out, according to Lemma A.2. For instance, when C1=0,C2=Cformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶10subscript𝐶2𝐶C_{1}=0,C_{2}=C, resulting Lipschitz constant simply becomes ‖𝒈˘(t)‖∞≤L˘∞=C1+0+2​(C−0)C​(1+0)=C+2≈2subscriptnormsuperscript˘𝒈𝑡subscript˘𝐿𝐶102𝐶0𝐶10𝐶22\|\breve{\boldsymbol{g}}^{(t)}\|_{\infty}\leq\breve{L}_{\infty}=\frac{C}{1+0}+\frac{2(C-0)}{C(1+0)}=C+2\approx 2, which is a constant far smaller than T𝑇T and K𝐾K, typically assumed in the practical cross-device FL setting. Therefore, for all experiments of AAggFF-D, we set C1=0,C2=Cformulae-sequencesubscript𝐶10subscript𝐶2𝐶C_{1}=0,C_{2}=C.

Appendix C Experimental Details

C.1 Datasets

For the main experiments in Table 2 and Table 3, we used 3 datasets for the cross-silo setting (Berka (Berka, 1999), MQP (McCreery et al., 2020), and ISIC (Codella et al., 2018; Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022)), and 3 other datasets for the cross-device setting (CelebA, Reddit (Caldas et al., 2019), and SpeechCommands (Warden, 2018)). In this section, we describe details of each dataset about its task, metrics, and client partitioning. The statistics of all federated benchmarks are summarized in Table A2. Note that Avg. and Std. in the table refer to the average and a standard deviation of a sample size of each client in the FL system

First, we present details of the federated benchmark for the cross-silo setting.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    Berka is a tabular dataset containing bank transaction records collected from Czech bank (Berka, 1999). Berka accompanies the loan default prediction task (i.e., binary classification) of each bank’s customers. It is fully anonymized and is originally composed of 8 relational tables: accounts, clients, disposition, loans, permanent orders, transactions, demographics, and credit cards. We merged all 8 tables into one dataset by joining the primary keys of each table, and finally have 15 input features. From the demographics table, we obtain information on the region: Prague, Central Bohemia, South Bohemia, West Bohemia, North Bohemia, East Bohemia, South Moravia, and North Moravia. We split each client according to the region and excluded all samples of North Bohemia since it has only one record of loan default, thus we finally have 7 clients (i.e., banks). Finally, we used the area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve for the evaluation metric.

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    MQP is a clinical question pair dataset crawled from medical question answering dataset (Ben Abacha & Demner-Fushman, 2019), and labeled by 11 doctors (McCreery et al., 2020). All paired sentences are labeled as either similar or dissimilar, thereby it is suitable for the binary classification task. As a pre-processing, we merge two paired sentences into one sentence by adding special tokens: [SEP], [PAD], and [UNK]. We set the maximum token length to 200, thus merged sentences less than 200 are filled with [PAD] tokens, and otherwise are truncated. Then, merged sentences are tokenized using pre-trained DistilBERT tokenizer (Sanh et al., 2019). We regard each doctor as a separate client and thus have 11 clients. Finally, we used the area under the ROC curve for the evaluation metric.

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    ISIC is a dermoscopic image dataset for a skin cancer classification, collected from 4 hospitals. (Codella et al., 2018; Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022) The task contains 8 distinct melanoma classes, thus designed for the multi-class classification task. Following (Ogier du Terrail et al., 2022), as one hospital has three different imaging apparatus, its samples are further divided into 3 clients, thus we finally have 6 clients in total. Finally, we used top-5 accuracy for the evaluation metric.

Next, we illustrate details of the federated benchmark for the cross-device setting.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    CelebA is a vision dataset containing the facial images of celebrities (Liu et al., 2015). It is curated for federated setting in LEAF benchmark (Caldas et al., 2019), and is targeted for the binary classification task (presence of smile). We follow the processing of (Caldas et al., 2019), thereby each client corresponds to each celebrity, having 9,343 total clients in the FL system. Finally, we used top-1 accuracy for the evaluation metric following (Caldas et al., 2019).

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    Reddit is a text dataset containing the comments of community users of Reddit in December 2017, and a part of LEAF benchmark (Caldas et al., 2019). Following (Caldas et al., 2019), we build a dictionary of vocabularies of size 10,000 from tokenized sentences and set the maximum sequence length to 10. The main task is tailored for language modeling, i.e., next token prediction, given word embeddings in each sentence of clients. Each client corresponds to one of the community users, thus 817 clients are presented in total. Finally, we used the top-1 accuracy for the evaluation metric following (Caldas et al., 2019).

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    SpeechCommands is designed for a short-length speech recognition task that includes one second 35 short-length words, such as “Up”, “Down”, “Left”, and “Right” (Warden, 2018). It is accordingly a multi-class classification task for 35 different classes. While it is collected from 2,618 speakers, we rule out all samples of speakers having too few samples when splitting the dataset into training and test sets. (e.g., exclude speakers whose total sample counts are less than 3) As a result, we have 2,005 clients, and each client has 16,000-length time-domain waveform samples. Finally, we used top-5 accuracy for the evaluation metric.

C.2 Models

For each dataset, we used task-specific model architectures which are already used in previous works, or widely used in reality, to simulate the practical FL scenario as much as possible. For the experiment of the cross-silo setting, we used the following models.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    Logistic Regression is used for the Berka dataset. We used a simple logistic regression model with a bias term, and the output (i.e., logit vector) is transformed into predicted class probabilities by the softmax function.

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    DistilBERT (Sanh et al., 2019) is used for the MQP dataset. We used a pre-trained DistilBERT model, from BookCorpus and English Wikipedia (Sanh et al., 2019). We also used the corresponding DistilBERT tokenizer for the pre-processing of raw clinical sentences. For a fine-tuning of the pre-trained DistilBERT model, we attach a classifier head next to the last layer of the DistilBERT’s encoder, which outputs an embedding of 768768768 dimension. The classifier is in detail processing the embedding as follows: (768768768-ReLU-Dropout-222), where each figure is an output dimension of a fully connected layer with a bias term, ReLU is a rectified linear unit activation layer, and Dropout (Srivastava et al., 2014) is a dropout layer having probability of 0.10.10.1. In the experiment, we trained all layers including pre-trained weights.

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    EfficientNet (Tan & Le, 2019) is used for the ISIC dataset. We also used the pre-trained EfficientNet-B0 model from ImageNet benchmark dataset (Deng et al., 2009). For fine-tuning, we attach a classifier head after the convolution layers of EfficientNet. The classifier is composed of the following components: (AdaptiveAvgPool(7,7777,7)-Dropout-888), where AdaptiveAvgPool(c​d​o​t,c​d​o​t𝑐𝑑𝑜𝑡𝑐𝑑𝑜𝑡cdot,cdot) is a 2D adaptive average pooling layer outputs a feature map of size 7×7777\times 7 (which are flattened thereafter), Dropout is a dropout layer with a probability of 0.1, and the last linear layer outputs an 8-dimensional vector, which is the total number of classes.

Next, for the cross-device setting, we used the following models.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    ConvNet model used in LEAF benchmark (Caldas et al., 2019) is used for the CelebA dataset. It is composed of four convolution layers, of which components are: 2D convolution layer without bias term with 32 filters of size 3×3333\times 3 (stride=1, padding=1), group normalization layer (the number of groups is decreased from 32 by a factor of 2: 32, 16, 8, 4), 2D max pooling layer with 2×2222\times 2 filters, and a ReLU nonlinear activation layer. Plus, a classifier comes after the consecutive convolution layers, which are composed of: (AdaptiveAvgPool(5,5555,5)-111), which are a 2D adaptive average pooling layer that outputs a feature map of size 5×5555\times 5 (which are flattened thereafter), and a linear layer with a bias term outputs a scalar value since it is a binary classification task.

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    StackedLSTM model used in LEAF benchmark (Caldas et al., 2019) is used for the Reddit dataset. It is composed of an embedding layer of which the number of embeddings is 200, and outputs an embedding vector of 256 dimensions. It is processed by consecutive 2 LSTM (Hochreiter & Schmidhuber, 1997) layers with the hidden size of 256, and enters the last linear layer with a bias term, which outputs a logit vector of 10,000 dimensions, which corresponds to the vocabulary size.

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    M5 (Dai et al., 2017) model is used for the SpeechCommands dataset. It is composed of four 1D convolution layers followed by a 1D batch normalization layer, ReLU nonlinear activation, and a 1D max pooling layer with a filter of size 4. All convolution layers EXCEPT the input layer have a filter of size 333, and the numbers of filters are 64, 128, and 256 (all with stride=1 and padding=1). The input convolution layer has 64 filters with a filter of size 808080, and stride of 444. Lastly, one linear layer outputs a logit vector of 35 dimensions.

C.3 Hyperparameters

Before the main experiment, we first tuned the hyperparameter of all baseline fair FL algorithms from a separate random seed. The hyperparameter of each fair algorithm is listed as follows.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    AFL (Mohri et al., 2019) — a step size of a mixing coefficient ∈\in{0.01, 0.1, 1.0}

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    q-FedAvg (Li et al., 2019) — a magnitude of fairness, ∈\in{0.1, 1.0, 5.0}

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    TERM (Li et al., 2020a) — a tilting constant, λ𝜆\lambda, ∈\in{0.1, 1.0, 10.0}

  4. ∙∙\bullet

    FedMGDA (Hu et al., 2022) — a deviation from static mixing coefficient ∈\in{0.1, 0.5, 1.0}

  5. ∙∙\bullet

    PropFair (Zhang et al., 2022) — a baseline constant ∈\in{2, 3, 5}

Each candidate value is selected according to the original paper, and we fix the number of local epochs, E=1𝐸1E=1 (following the set up in (Li et al., 2019)), along with the number of local batch size B=20𝐵20B=20 in all experiments. For each dataset, a weight decay (L2 penalty) factor (ψ𝜓\psi), a local learning rate (ζ𝜁\zeta), and variables related to a learning rate scheduling (i.e., learning rate decay factor (ϕitalic-ϕ\phi), and a decay step (s𝑠s)) are tuned first with FedAvg (McMahan et al., 2017) as follows.

  1. ∙∙\bullet

    Berka: ψ=10−3,ζ=100,ϕ=0.99,s=10formulae-sequence𝜓superscript103formulae-sequence𝜁superscript100formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.99𝑠10\psi=10^{-3},\zeta=10^{0},\phi=0.99,s=10

  2. ∙∙\bullet

    MQP: ψ=10−2,ζ=10−52,ϕ=0.99,s=15formulae-sequence𝜓superscript102formulae-sequence𝜁superscript1052formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.99𝑠15\psi=10^{-2},\zeta=10^{-\frac{5}{2}},\phi=0.99,s=15

  3. ∙∙\bullet

    ISIC: ψ=10−2,ζ=10−4,ϕ=0.95,s=5formulae-sequence𝜓superscript102formulae-sequence𝜁superscript104formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.95𝑠5\psi=10^{-2},\zeta=10^{-4},\phi=0.95,s=5

  4. ∙∙\bullet

    CelebA: ψ=10−4,ζ=10−1,ϕ=0.96,s=300formulae-sequence𝜓superscript104formulae-sequence𝜁superscript101formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.96𝑠300\psi=10^{-4},\zeta=10^{-1},\phi=0.96,s=300

  5. ∙∙\bullet

    Reddit: ψ=10−6,ζ=1078,ϕ=0.95,s=20formulae-sequence𝜓superscript106formulae-sequence𝜁superscript1078formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.95𝑠20\psi=10^{-6},\zeta=10^{\frac{7}{8}},\phi=0.95,s=20

  6. ∙∙\bullet

    SpeechCommands: ψ=0,ζ=10−1,ϕ=0.999,s=10formulae-sequence𝜓0formulae-sequence𝜁superscript101formulae-sequenceitalic-ϕ0.999𝑠10\psi=0,\zeta=10^{-1},\phi=0.999,s=10

This is intended under the assumption that all fair FL algorithms should at least be effective in the same setting of the FL algorithm with the static aggregation scheme (i.e., FedAvg). Note that client-side optimization in all experiments is done by the Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD) optimizer.

C.4 Implementation Details

All code is implemented in PyTorch (Paszke et al., 2019), simulating a central parameter server that orchestrates a whole FL procedure and operates AAggFF. We further simulate K𝐾K participating clients having their own local samples, and a communication scheme with the central server. All experiments are conducted on a server with 2 Intel®Xeon®Gold 6226R CPUs (@ 2.90GHz) and 2 NVIDIA®Tesla®V100-PCIE-32GB GPUs.

Appendix D Pseudocode for AAggFF

D.1 Pseudocode for ClientUpdate

For generating a response vector, each client is requested to evaluate the received global model on its training samples, {ξk}k=1nisuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜉𝑘𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑖\{\xi_{k}\}_{k=1}^{n_{i}}, before the local update. As a result of the evaluation, the local loss of client i𝑖i at round t𝑡t, i.e., Fi​(𝜽(t))subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right), is calculated as follows.

Fi​(𝜽(t))=1ni​∑k=1niℒ​(ξk;𝜽(t)),subscript𝐹𝑖superscript𝜽𝑡1subscript𝑛𝑖superscriptsubscript𝑘1subscript𝑛𝑖ℒsubscript𝜉𝑘superscript𝜽𝑡\displaystyle F_{i}\left(\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right)=\frac{1}{n_{i}}\sum_{k=1}^{n_{i}}\mathcal{L}\left(\xi_{k};\boldsymbol{\theta}^{(t)}\right), (94)

where nisubscript𝑛𝑖n_{i} is the total sample size of client i𝑖i, l𝑙l is a loss function specific to the task, and h𝜽subscriptℎ𝜽h_{\boldsymbol{\theta}} is a hypothesis realized by the parameter 𝜽𝜽\boldsymbol{\theta}.

D.2 Pseudocode for AAggFF-S

D.3 Pseudocode for AAggFF-D

After updating whole entries of a decision variable, the server only exploits mixing coefficients of which indices correspond to selected clients. Denoting as 𝒑~(t+1)∈Δ|S(t)|−1superscript~𝒑𝑡1subscriptΔsuperscript𝑆𝑡1\tilde{\boldsymbol{p}}^{(t+1)}\in\Delta_{|S^{(t)}|-1}, each selected entry is normalized as follows.

p~i(t+1)=pi(t+1)∑j∈S(t)pj(t+1),i∈S(t)formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript~𝑝𝑖𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡1subscript𝑗superscript𝑆𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑗𝑡1𝑖superscript𝑆𝑡\displaystyle\tilde{p}_{i}^{(t+1)}=\frac{p_{i}^{(t+1)}}{\sum_{j\in S^{(t)}}p_{j}^{(t+1)}},i\in S^{(t)} (95)

This ensures that selected coefficients also satisfy the condition for being a probability vector (i.e., sum up to 1).
